X A session that started on an uncertain note pulled off healthy gains Monday, as rising prices and a rally in security and small cap stocks sent the indexes higher.The Nasdaq popped 0.5% to take a new high, despite Tesla's (TSLA) 3% decline and a 0.3% pullback by Apple (AAPL), and as IBD 50 stocks NetEase (NTES) and Nvida (NVDA) each gained about 5%.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 logged a 0.5% gain. The S&P 500 also took out new highs, both intraday and at the close, as Qorvo (QRVO), Nvidia and NetApp (NTAP) posted its three strongest gains.Trade was higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) topped the Dow industrials index, boosted by an upgrade to overweight. The move lifted the stock back above 10-week moving average and up the right side of a flat base with a 129.10 buy point.Verizon Communications (VZ) was the only Dow stock to drop 1% or more.Security software plays were among the day's big winners, as Goldman Sachs named several leading names in the response to the WannaCry global ransomware attacks. Mimecast (MIME) spiked 11%, FireEye (FEYE)bolted 8% and Proofpoint (PFPT) gained 7%.  Proofpoint ended 4% above an 82.09 buy point and an alternative entry at 84.46.On the IBD 50, NetEase's strong-volume 5% advance drove shares back above their 10-week moving average as the stock works on a cup base. Nvidia is extended and ticking off new highs above a 121.02 flat base buy point.Workday (WDAY) ended the day not quite 4% above a 92.10 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) slipped 0.9% before the closing bell, then bolted 5% higher upon reporting its first-quarter results after the close.On Tuesday, Home Depot (HD), Stratasys (SSYS), TJMaxx (TJX) and Sina (SINA) are among the stocks expected to deliver early earnings results.RELATED: Home Depot Near High, 2 others Near Buys: Investing Action Plan Stratasys Earnings Up Next As 3D Printer Stocks Take Flight

Western Digital (WDC) received a 45% price-target increase and an upgrade from JPMorgan, as the market for disk drives and memory chips move in its direction.The upgrade to overweight from neutral from analyst Rod Hall was based partly on improving conditions in the PC market and a shortage of memory chips that is keeping prices high — two markets where Western Digital is a major player. Hall also wrote that Western Digital also has significant potential for cost reductions, following its acquisitions of memory chip companies SanDisk and Hitachi Global Storage Technologies.Hall also raised his price target on Western Digital to 116, from 80.Western Digital stock was up 1.5% to close at 86.05 on the stock market today. The stock earlier hit a high of 88 before pulling back as overall market conditions worsened. Western Digital stock is up 42% since hitting a low of 34.99 in May.Western Digital is benefiting from a shortage of Nand memory chips, which Hall thinks will continue into the fourth quarter."We note that the Nand supply continues to be tight, as flagged by multiple companies, including HP (HPE) and NetApp (NTAP)," Hall wrote in a research note Tuesday.He raised his outlook for disk drive shipments by 5%, "driven by an improving PC market as well as the ongoing Nand shortage, which we expect to continue to drive increased hard disk drive demand."Angelo Zino, equity analyst at CFRA, also upgraded Western Digital on Tuesday, to a strong buy from buy, and raised his price target to 100, from 92.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital has been added to the IBD Leaderboard list of top-performing stocks on March 30. The stock sports a strong IBD Composite Rating of 96, meaning it has outperformed all stocks over the past six months. based on a variety of metrics."We see hard disk drive conditions aided by prior capacity cuts and stable PC demand," Zino wrote.Western Digital and Seagate Technology (STX) are the two largest suppliers of disk drives. On Tuesday, Longbow Research upgraded Seagate to buy from neutral, with a price target of 55. Seagate stock climbed 3.1% to 49.09.Hall also believes Western Digital is likely considering making a bid for Toshiba Memory. In February, Toshiba said it was looking to sell its memory chip business, which has drawn the interest of about 10 companies, including chipmaker Broadcom (AVGO). RELATED: Broadcom Joins Bidding For Toshiba Chip UnitWestern Digital Gets Positive Reviews On 'Crisp Execution'

A chipmaker and a telecom player bore the brunt of undesirable ratings from Wall Street on Thursday, while a couple of tech firms got positive signals.Chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) was initiated at sell and T-Mobile US (TMUS) got a downgrade to hold prior to Thursday's open. But NetApp (NTAP) was upgraded to market perform, while DXC Technology (DXC) moved up to outperform status.Goldman Sachs initiated coverage of AMD with a sell rating and price target of 11. AMD stock plunged 6.3% to 13.28 on the stock market today. AMD stock has shot up 500% over the past 12 months.But Goldman analyst Toshiya Hari expects competitive threats from Intel (INTC). "We find current valuation multiples difficult to justify as the market seems to have already priced in a sharp improvement in AMD's competitive and financial position," Hari said in a report. "We expect shares to underperform the market post the May analyst day given the company's strong performance over the last 16 months and a higher bar on the execution front."RELATED:Nvidia Stock Gets Price Target Cut On Near-Term Growth ChallengesDeutsche Bank downgraded the wireless phone company to hold from buy. Shares in T-Mobile, controlled by Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), fell 0.4% to 63.24 on Wednesday. T-Mobile has been gaining revenue and subscriber share vs. AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) with its "Uncarrier"-branded advertising. However, analysts have lowered first-quarter estimates amid intensified competition.T-Mobile, Comcast May Win In Surprise Auction Spectrum Grab: UBSAT&T, Verizon Earnings Estimates Pressured By Unlimited Data BattleJMP Securities upgraded the data-storage and networking company to market perform following its investor day. Piper Jaffray bumped its price target on NetApp to 50 from 49. NetApp stock edged up 0.4% to close at 41.05 on Thursday."Management expects low-single-digit revenue growth, driven by the increasing adoption of all-flash arrays," a Piper Jaffray report said. "More importantly, management expects this growth to  drive gross and operating-margin expansion, reaching 18% to 22% in 2018-20."RELATED:Cloudy Forecast Good For Computer Data Storage FirmsMorgan Stanley upgraded DXC Technology with an overweight rating. DXC stock was up more than 4% to 74.68 at the close Thursday after gaining 3.4% on Wednesday. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) on Monday completed the spinoff of its enterprise services businesses, which merged with Computer Sciences Corp. to create DXC Technology. RBC Capital on Tuesday rated DXC a buy with a price target of 87.RELATED:HP Enterprise, DXC Technology Shares Slip Post-SpinoffIn other analyst moves, Goldman Sachs initiated Cedar Fair (FUN) with a buy rating; Wells Fargo upgraded Keysight Technology (KEYS) to outperform; JPMorgan downgraded Bunge (BG) to underweight; and Morgan Stanley downgraded Aercap Holding (AER) and Air Lease (AL) to equal weight.

Computer hardware giant Dell Technologies (DVMT) on Thursday reported strong fiscal fourth-quarter results that have positive implications for peers like HP Inc. (HPQ) and NetApp (NTAP) as well as other tech firms.Round Rock, Texas-based Dell said its sales in the quarter ended Feb. 3 were $20.1 billion, up 53% from the year-earlier period, which was before Dell purchased data storage tech firm EMC. It reported adjusted net income of $1.1 billion for the quarter.Dell Technologies describes itself as the world's largest privately controlled technology company. PC and server maker Dell, which went private in October 2013, purchased EMC last September to create Dell Technologies. At the same time, it issued a tracking stock for its stake in EMC spinoff VMware (VMW).Revenue in Dell's client solutions group, which includes PCs and displays, rose 11% year over year to $9.8 billion. That is its best performance in more than eight quarters, RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a report Thursday."While the company did not provide April-quarter guidance, we think January-quarter's results have better implications for the PC businesses of PC-exposed companies," Daryanani said. He listed PC maker HP, chipmaker Intel (INTC), tech reseller CDW (CDW) and hard-disk-drive makers Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) as benefiting from improving industry conditions.IBD'S TAKE: Dell Technologies stock has been forming a flat base for four weeks with a buy point of 65.88. The stock recently was added to IBD's Leaderboard list of stocks with potential for big gains.Dell shipped 11 million PCs in the fourth quarter, its largest volume since the fourth quarter of 2011. Its personal computer shipments were up 8.2% year over year.Dell's infrastructure solutions group generated $8.4 billion in revenue in the fourth quarter. That included $3.6 billion from servers and networking and $4.8 billion from storage. VMware revenue for the fourth quarter was $1.9 billion, Dell reported."Dell's server and networking performance should also have positive implications for the server/data center segments of Intel, Western Digital, Seagate and CDW," Daryanani said. NetApp should benefit from the same trends helping Dell's storage business, he said.

Data storage and management provider NetApp (NTAP) received a bundle of positive comments by analysts, following its quarterly earnings report late Wednesday that beat expectations, as did its outlook.NetApp stock jumped 4.2% to 40.56 in the stock market today, after earlier rising to 42.18, its highest price since December 2014.IBD'S TAKE: Which companies are hitting 52-week highs? That's easy to find at IBD's New Highs, but that list goes one big step better. That is, it ranks the companies making new highs by Composite Rating. So the best are at the top, making this a quick and easy read to find stocks for your watchlist.NetApp is among the leading providers of storage and data management solutions, including a line of storage arrays based on flash-storage chips. NetApp reported revenue of $1.4 billion, slightly above the consensus estimate of $1.39 billion. That was up just 1% year over year, but was its first revenue growth in 13 quarters. It reported earnings per share minus items of 82 cents, above the consensus of 74 cents and up 17%, for the company's fiscal third quarter ended Jan. 27. It was the best EPS performance in 10 quarters.William Blair analyst Jason Ader upgraded NetApp to market perform from underperform, though he did not set a price target. Ader cited improved product positioning in recent quarters at NetApp, especially in the all-flash market.Ader says EMC will continue to experience disruptions related to its September acquisition by Dell for the next few quarters. He also sees expanding profitability resulting from cost reductions."We concede that we have not been believers in NetApp's turnaround; but recent results speak for themselves, and we cannot deny that NetApp has gotten back on track," Ader wrote in a research note. "Still, we continue to see risks ahead given intense competition in the storage market and headwinds from the public cloud, which keep us from moving to an outperform rating."UBS analyst Steven Milunovich maintained a sell rating on NetApp but raised his price target to 37 from 32. In a research note, Milunovich said NetApp CEO George Kurian "is playing his hand well."Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White maintained a buy rating and raised his price target to 62 from 52."NetApp delivered another strong quarterly report and we believe sentiment around the stock has the potential for meaningful improvement," White wrote in a report.Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha maintained an underperform rating on NetApp but raised his price target to 32 from 29.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani raised his price target to 45 from 40, with a sector perform rating.RELATED:Dividend Names NetApp, Analog Devices Set Up In BasesNetEase Crushes Q4 Earnings On Online Games; Stock Soars To Record HighApplied Materials Beats Q1 Targets, Guides Higher, Stock RisesCBS Revenue Hit By NFL, Barrick Gold Beats; Goldcorp, Kinross Mixe

A byproduct of the digital economy is the ginormous amount of data that corporations and other enterprises, as well as consumers, are storing online in the internet cloud. That has been a boon for makers of data storage computers and their key components, namely hard disk drives (HDD) and solid state drives that use flash memory. Investors have responded by…

Data-storage systems provider NetApp (NTAP) reported quarterly earnings after the close Wednesday that beat on the top and bottom lines, as did its forecast.NetApp reported revenue of $1.4 billion, slightly above the consensus estimate of $1.39 billion. That was up just 1% year over year, but that is its first revenue growth in 13 quarters. The revenue rise suggests the decline in NetApp's legacy storage business might have bottomed out.It reported earnings per share minus items of 82 cents, above the consensus of 74 cents and up 17%, for the company's fiscal third quarter ended Jan. 27. It was the best EPS performance in 10 quarters.NetApp stock was up 3.4% at 40.25 in late trading in the stock market today. NetApp is trading near three-year highs and is approaching a buy zone after breaking out of a cup base at 39.10 last week.IBD'S TAKE: Which companies are hitting 52-week highs? That easy to find at IBD's New Highs, but that list goes one big step better. That is, it ranks the companies making new highs by Composite Rating. So the best are at the top, making this a quick and easy read to find stocks for your watch list.For fiscal Q4, NetApp expects revenue of $1.365 billion to $1.515 billion, above the consensus of $1.4 billion at the midpoint. It projects EPS minus items of 79 cents to 84 cents, above the consensus of 77 cents.The company has been challenged by intense competition among providers of flash storage products, a transition to cloud, and the emergence of "hyperconverged infrastructure" products like those made by Nutanix (NTNX), which held its initial public offering in September.Nutanix technology is disruptive to traditional information technology infrastructure. Nutanix products have replaced traditional silos of servers, storage and networking gear with a converged system that combines storage, computing and software into one package, based on lower-cost hardware.Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White has a buy rating on NetApp and price target of 52.NetApp's rapidly growing flash business and a leaner cost structure are among the reasons White, in a research note, said that "NetApp has the potential for meaningful improvement."Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha, on the other hand, rates the stock underperform, with a price target of 29."While the company has executed well in recent quarters, we see secular challenges remain to both topline and profitability," Garcha wrote in a report. "NetApp may continue losing market share to smaller rivals, while also being disrupted by the move to public cloud."RELATED:Dividend Names NetApp, Analog Devices Set Up In BasesNetEase Crushes Q4 Earnings On Online Games; Stock Soars To Record HighApplied Materials Beats Q1 Targets, Guides Higher, Stock RisesCBS Revenue Hit By NFL, Barrick Gold Beats; Goldcorp, Kinross Mixed

It's a hard to overstate the impact computers have had on our lives — and that impact appears set to multiply going forward. So it's no surprise that the Computer sector ranks a powerful No. 3 on Tuesday among the 33 sectors tracked by IBD. The sector, which is made up of four separate industry groups, has a 13.1% year-to-date…

Stocks climbed to record highs early Thursday before slipping into the red. Earnings drove big moves, with Cisco Systems (CSCO) leading the Dow Jones industrial average.By midmorning, the Dow and Nasdaq composite were flirting with the flat line. The S&P 500 edged 0.2% lower. Small caps lagged, with the Russell 2000 down 0.3%. Volume was tracking lower across the board in the stock market today vs. the same time Wednesday.Data-storage, fiber-optic and hotel stocks were among the biggest gainers, while department-store, managed-care and casino stocks lagged.Cisco led the Dow with a 3% pop in furious trade to its highest level in more than nine years, after the networking gear giant beat fiscal Q2 views late Wednesday and boosted its dividend. Shares are now out of buy range from a flat base cleared earlier this week. UBS and Deutsche Bank raised their price targets. Both have buy ratings on the stock.NetEase (NTES) outperformed on the IBD 50 as it gapped up and surged 8% to a new high in rapid turnover. Shares, which closed Wednesday in buy range from a 257.78 cup-with-handle entry, are now well-extended. The Chinese online gaming company reported better-than-expected Q4 earnings and revenue after the close Wednesday, boosted by mobile gaming strength.NetApp (NTAP) also gapped up and soared 8% in massive trade after its quarterly results late Wednesday topped views. The stock is also now extended past a 39.10 flat-base buy point. The data storage company also guided its fiscal Q4 earnings outlook above consensus estimates.On the downside, Avis Budget (CAR) plunged 12%, gapping below its 50-day line in heavy volume before finding support at its 200-day. Shares are back near the bottom of a shallow consolidation. The car-rental chain's Q4 results fell more than expected.MGM Resorts International (MGM) lost 8% in huge trade after its Q4 revenue beat forecasts, but earnings missed. Shares gapped down below the 50-day line and undercut the low of a flat base the casino operator had been building, though the stock is still within the 15% correction range for a flat-base pattern.In economic news, weekly jobless claims increased to 239,000 from the prior week's 234,000, vs. economists' forecasts for 246,000. January housing starts slipped to a 1.246 million annualized rate from an upwardly revised 1.279 million in December, but above expectations for 1.232 million. Permits jumped to 1.285 million, beating views.RELATED:Cisco, NetApp, Applied Materials, CBS Price Targets Hiked

Stocks opened higher Thursday, as earnings reports drove much of the major moves.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 edged up 0.1% and the Nasdaq gained 0.3%.The past two sessions have logged cool starts and hot finishes, adding to a seven-day run-up for the Nasdaq and S&P 500 that has left both indexes at fresh highs. The Dow also has knocked off consecutive new highs with a five-day rally. A five-day streak also drove the Russell 2000 to a record, closing narrowly above the 1400 mark for the first time on Wednesday.Barrick Gold (ABX), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Shire (SHPG) were among the stocks gaining ground after reporting quarterly results. Kraft Heinz (KHC) and Waste Management (WM) fell 2%.Casino owner Melco Crown (MPEL) rose 2% on fourth-quarter results, and on news that Melco International Development had acquired a majority interest in the company. The stock is just above a 17.93 cup-with-handle buy point.MGM International (MGM) shed 8% after reporting its fourth-quarter results. A 12% revenue gain narrowly topped forecasts, but earnings stopped well short of views. The stock has been in a flat-base consolidation since early December, but it gapped down below the 50-day line, to the lows of the pattern.NetEase (NTES) scored a 10% gain at the open. The China-based provider of online games reported better-than-forecast fourth-quarter results late Wednesday, with mobile gaming helping to send revenue up 43% and earnings to a 57% gain. Management also boosted the quarterly dividend to $1.01, up from 78 cents in the third quarter. NetEase is now extended above a 257.78 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Data storage leader NetApp (NTAP) jumped 8% at the open. Its fiscal third-quarter results posted late Wednesday easily topped analyst targets, and fourth-quarter earnings guidance was above consensus views. The stock is now extended from a 39.10 flat-base buy point.Avis Budget (CAR) tanked 12% after reporting its fourth-quarter revenue and earnings declined more than projected by analysts. The company cited weak pricing and higher per-unit fleet costs. The stock gapped below its 10-week moving average.Molina Healthcare (MOH) tumbled 16% as investors reacted to the company's unexpected fourth-quarter loss of $1.54 per share, vs. expectations for a 78-cent per-share profit. Revenue grew less than expected, and 2017 guidance was mixed, with earnings well below consensus views. It cited difficulties operating in the ObamaCare marketplaces.Housing starts and building permits diverged, not an unusual occurrence in January as winter weather slows project starts and builders began pulling permits for spring work. Starts dipped to an annualized rate of 1.246 million, the Commerce Department reported.  That was below an upwardly revised December rate of 1.279 million starts.   Economists had predicted a mild uptick to 1.232 million starts.Permits surged to an annualized rate of 1.285 million, up from 1.210 million in January and well above projections for 1.233 million.First-time unemployment claims edged up to 239,000 in the week ended Feb. 11, vs. 234,000 claims in the prior week, the Labor Department reported. Economists had projected a jump to 246,000 claims. The four-week moving average turned up to 245,250, its second advance in three weeks.The Conference Board delivers its leading economic indicators for January at 10 a.m. ET.Markets in Europe traded lower in afternoon action, with the CAC 40 in Paris down 0.4% and London's FTSE 100 off by 0.3%. China's exchanges marked a positive session, with the Shanghai Compoiste and the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong each rising 0.5%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended Wednesday's session down 0.5%.RELATED:F-35; MGM, Melco Near Buy Points: Investing Action Plan

Analyst actions on Tuesday included upgrades of Under Armour (UAA), NetApp (NTAP) and Zillow (ZG), a price target hike for Restaurant Brands International (QSR) and new coverage for CyberArk Software (CYBR).Morgan Stanley raised its rating on the performance apparel company to equal-weight from underweight, while reducing its price target to 20 from 25. Analyst Jay Sole cut his rating on the company to underweight in January 2016. Now, based on the stock's long slide, he says the market agrees with him that it is "a much more mature brand than it previously thought."In late January, Under Armour forecast "tempered" sales growth for 2017 and said its CFO was leaving.Shares of Under Armour rose 2.1% to close at 21.76 on the stock market today.RELATED:Under Armour In Tailspin On Sales, Outlook; Is Kohl's Rollout A Life Vest?Piper Jaffray upgraded the maker of network storage and date-management products to overweight from neutral, raising its price target to 46 from 37. Analyst Andrew Nowinski cited its competitive position, improving demand, and an ability to deliver mid-single-digit revenue growth and scale up to 20% operating margins. NetApp reports earnings after the market closes on Thursday.Shares of NetApp finished 0.15% lower at 39.524 on the stock market today.RELATED:NetApp Pops To 21-Month High, Transition To Cloud Picks Up SteamStifel started coverage on the Israeli provider of network security software with a buy rating and 62 price target.Analyst Gur Talpaz said CyberArk's solutions are "unique within the cadre of public security software vendors," because they focus on keeping "bad human actors" from gaining control of mission-critical systems." The company is the "clear leader" in the emerging Privileged Account Management market, Stifel said.Shares of CyberArk rose 2.7% to 54.32.RELATED:CyberArk's Solid Earnings Push Stock Closer To Buy PointUBS hiked its price target for the operator of the Burger King and Tim Hortons to 60 from 55, keeping a buy rating. RBC Capital bumped its target up to 59 from 54, with an outperform rating.RBC analyst David Palmer cited favorable growth and spending trends, and spotlighted M&A as "an area of additional upside."On Monday, Restaurant Brands beat fourth-quarter earnings estimates, and Reuters reported that the company approached Popeyes Louisiana Chicken (PLKI) about a takeover.Restaurant Brands rose 1.4% to 54.53.RELATED:Popeyes Shares Pop As Burger King Parent Reportedly Eyes BuyoutBurger King Parent Restaurant Brands Beats Q4 ForecastsStifel raised the online real estate group to buy from hold, lifting the price target to 43 from 36. Analyst George Askew says the company appears to have implemented a price hike of about 50% "on leads within its Premier Agent program for new contracts."IBD previously reported that Zillow rolled out a new dynamic approach to pricing of its Premier Agent ads. Under the new system, prices are set dynamically, based on the total dollars agents budget to advertise on Zillow in a given ZIP code.Zillow's ZG shares roes 2.7% to 35.72. Z-class shares gained 3% to 36.30.RELATED:Zillow In Position To Dominate Online Real Estate Ad Market

The Dow Jones industrial average and other major indexes hit record highs as President Trump made more noises about tax reform, while Fed chief Janet Yellen took a slightly hawkish stance. Apple (AAPL) rose to an all-time best while fellow Dow stock Verizon Communications (VZ) returned to unlimited wireless plans. Kraft Heinz (KHC) is pursuing a mammoth deal for Unilever (UN). NetEase (NTES), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and NetApp (NTAP) rallied on earnings, while General Motors (GM) may sell its European unit Opel.The Dow industrials and Nasdaq composite rose 1.8% for the week, with the S&P 500 added 1.5%, all hitting new highs during the week. Apple was a key contributor to all the major indexes. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's somewhat hawkish tone didn't worry investors, but gave bond yields and bank stocks a boost."Waiting too long to remove accommodation would be unwise," Fed chief Janet Yellen told Congress, a shift from her 2016 tone emphasizing downside risks to the economy. Yellen, along with other Fed officials speaking during the week, raised the odds of a near-term hike slightly. Markets don't expect a March move but see a 50-50 move by May and a strong likelihood by June.  Yellen warned against repealing financial regulations passed after the credit crisis.Meanwhile, retail sales and inflation data were stronger than expected, while small-business optimism hit a fresh 12-year high and the Philly Fed manufacturing index shot up to its strongest reading since 1984.RELATED:Worries over intensified wireless competition pressured phone company stocks after Verizon Communications (VZ) reintroduced unlimited data plans nearly six years after removing them. Verizon sought an edge over T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) by offering high-definition video as part of unlimited data. T-Mobile quickly changed its offer to include HD video. Sprint cut its unlimited price to $50 a month or $90 for two users, including HD video. AT&T (T) opened unlimited wireless beyond DirecTV and U-verse customers. Analysts say industry consolidation could ease competition. Merger talks are expected to heat up when a government spectrum auctions ends, perhaps by late March.RELATED:T-Mobile (TMUS) on Feb. 14 reported Q4 profit and revenue that edged views. For 2017, it forecast branded postpaid subscriber additions of 2.9 million, below estimates. Analysts called the guidance conservative, though in any event T-Mobile will likely lead industry subscriber growth for the fourth year in a row in 2017. For the first time, T-Mobile provided free cash flow guidance. It forecast three-year FCF annual growth of 45% to 48%, or about $4.5 billion by 2019.Softbank is willing to give up control of its majority-owned Sprint to achieve a merger with T-Mobile, Reuters reported Friday. Sprint rose 3.3% on Friday and T-Mobile 5.5%, with AT&T and Verizon rising modestly that day.RELATED:Apple, the top Dow industrials stock in 2017, hit a record high of 136.27 on news reports related to its cash-return plans and the upcoming iPhone 8. Apple reportedly increased its order of OLED displays from Samsung for its 10th-anniversary smartphone, due out in September. CFO Luca Maestri said Apple would look to boost dividends and buybacks if the U.S. cuts corporate tax rates, as expected under President Trump.RELATED:Kraft Heinz (KHC) signaled it will continue to pursue the European consumer and food products giant even though Unilever (UN) said the offer undervalued the company and sees no reason for further talks. A combination would be one of the largest of all time and create a global food giant. Kraft Heinz, which has been slashing costs to boost profit, shot up 10.6% Friday to a record high. Unilever leapt 15.3% to 48.79, also setting a record best. Snacks giant Mondelez (MDLZ) fell. Consumer products firms such as Kimberly-Clark (KMB) rallied.RELATED:President Trump on Wednesday met with CEOs from Target (TGT), Gap (GPS), AutoZone (AZO) and other retailers, saying he would cut regulations and encouraging them to expand in the U.S. Trump also said a "massive" tax plan was coming "in the not-too-distant future." Target, afterward, warned that a GOP plan for a border adjustment tax as part of corporate tax reform would force them to "raise prices for American families on everyday essentials." That subject came up during the meeting, although it was unclear how much of a focus it was.RELATED:Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) gobbled up shares of Apple (AAPL) in Q4, quadrupling its holdings, according to a regulatory filing. He also continued to fill up on Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines (AAL) and United Airlines (UAL). David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital also boosted its stake in Apple. Appaloosa cut its stake in the iPhone maker but hiked its stake in Southwest (LUV). George Soros took stakes in Facebook (FB), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Delta, but dropped United. Activist investor Trian Fund Management built up a $3.5 billion position in Procter & Gamble (PG).RELATED:The Chinese mobile gaming giant late Wednesday reported Q4 earnings per American depositary receipt of $4.40 minus items on revenue of $1.74 billion, both well above the analyst consensus. Online game revenue rose 63% in local currency to $1.29 billion. NetEase said it added 40 mobile titles in 2016, and in December it announced 14 new PC and mobile games. NetEase licenses many games from Activision Blizzard (ATVI), including "World of Warcraft" and "Overwatch." NetEase stock leapt 14% on Thursday to a record high after edging past a buy point earlier in the week.RELATED: In its fiscal Q2 ended Jan. 28, Cisco earned 57 cents per share minus items, flat from a year earlier but topping views by a penny. Revenue fell 2% to $11.58 billion, the fifth straight decline, but that beat expectations of $11.55 billion. Cisco's deferred revenue from software and subscriptions jumped 51% to $4 billion in fiscal Q2, a sign that its shift to software and services from its core business of selling network switches and routers is gaining momentum. Cisco shares rose 7%, hitting their best levels since November 2007.RELATED:Chip gear maker Applied Materials (AMAT) earned 67 cents a share ex items in its fiscal Q1, up 158% year over year, on sales of $3.28 billion, up 45%. Analysts expected 66 cents and $3.27 billion. It was Applied Materials' fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales and EPS growth. For fiscal Q2, Applied Materials sees strong earnings and sales growth that are above Wall Street models. Applied Materials shares rose 1%, near 16-year highs.RELATED:Data storage systems provider NetApp reported earnings and guidance that topped views. Revenue of $1.4 billion edged past the consensus of $1.39 billion and was its first top-line growth in 13 quarters. NetApp rose 4.2% on Thursday, moving back above a 39.10 buy point from a cup base.RELATED:U.S. crude futures fell 0.9% to $53.40 a barrel for the week. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries now sees non-OPEC supplies growing by 240,000 barrels per day, double it prior estimate, as drilling and investment pick up in the U.S. OPEC also said in its oil market report that its production fell by 890,200 bpd in January. Saudi Arabia had the biggest decline in output. U.S. crude stockpiles jumped by 9.5 million barrels, according to the Energy Information Administration, well above analyst estimates. But stocks at the Cushing, Okla., hub were down. The number of U.S. oil rigs in operation rose yet again. Diamondback Energy (FANG) reported Q4 results above Wall Street views and raised its full-year production outlook and capital-spending target. Devon Energy (DVN) also reported Q4 results above expectations.RELATED:Peugeot's parent, PSA Group, said it was in talks with General Motors (GM) about potentially acquiring the U.S. automaker's Opel division, which also includes the British Vauxhall brand. The deal would give PSA Group a 16% market share in Europe, second only to Volkswagen (VLKAY). GM has had trouble turning a profit at the unit and had a tentative deal in 2009 to sell it to Canada's Magna.RELATED:One big health insurance merger, between Aetna (AET) and Humana (HUM), is dead, while the other, between Anthem (ANTM) and Cigna (CI), broke out into a wrestling match. Federal judges blocked both deals earlier this year. Cigna sued Anthem for $13 billion in damages on top of a $1.85 billion breakup fee. But a judge blocked Cigna from ending the merger after Anthem countersued, arguing that Cigna has tried to sabotage the deal.Humana, which gets a $1 billion payment from Aetna for its trouble, moved on by announcing a stock buyback and saying it will exit the ObamaCare exchanges. Aetna's CEO said the ObamaCare exchanges are in a death spiral. And Molina Health (MOH) signaled it would likely exit the ObamaCare exchanges next year.UnitedHealth (UNH) tumbled 3.7% Friday on news that the Justice Department has joined a whistleblower suit accusing the health insurer of overcharging Medicare Advantage by hundreds of millions of dollars, possibly billions of dollars. Other health insurers, including Aetna and Humana also retreated Friday.RELATED:DOJ Accuses UnitedHealth Of Overcharging Medicare AdvantageSnap (SNAP), in an updated SEC filing, says it's looking to 200 million shares at a price range of 14 to 16 a share, raising roughly $3 billion. That would give it a valuation of $19.5 billion to $22.2 billion, below earlier reports that the Snapchat parent would seek $25 billion. Snapchat enjoys rapid revenue growth, but Facebook (FB) is successfully imitating Snapchat features, especially on its Instagram app.RELATED:U.S. Steel (X) flirted with a buy point during the week while Steel Dynamics (STLD) and Nucor (NUE) and aluminum maker Alcoa (AA) jumped on reports that China is considering sweeping production cuts to combat smog. Reuters reported that China could slash steel capacity by at least half and aluminum capacity by 30% in certain months.Cement and aggregates firms, like steel companies, are expected to benefit from President Trump's infrastructure push, as well as a multibillion-dollar wall on the border, but that won't help 2017 results much. Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) on Tuesday missed fourth-quarter earnings and sales estimates and gave a subdued 2017 outlook.RELATED:Las-Vegas-centric MGM Resorts International (MGM) turned profitable in Q4, reversing a year-earlier loss, but missed estimates, while revenue was in line. Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL), which operates out of gaming hub Macau and elsewhere in Asia, topped views on sales but missed on EPS. Macau has been trying to recover after the Chinese government launched an anti-money-laundering crackdown.  MGM fell 9.3% on Thursday to a three-month low. Melco fell 4.5% after briefly retaking a buy point in the morning.RELATED:ON Semiconductor (ON) rose 10.1% through Thursday, hitting its best levels since August 2000, after the chipmaker on Sunday reported adjusted EPS rose 53% and sales climbed 50%, both beating. Q1 guidance also was strong.Shopify (SHOP) hit a record high after the e-commerce platform provider reported Q4 earnings that topped views as revenue grew 86% to $130.4 million. Q1 revenue guidance was strong.Mobileye (MBLY) and Volkswagen (VLKAY) will partner in the development and deployment of self-driving cars. The two will implement "a new navigation standard for autonomous driving starting in 2018." Mobileye already has an autonomous-car deal with BMW. It also is sharing data with Here, a mapping service owned by German automakers including BMW and VW's Audi.

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen will testify on Capitol Hill, and Congress will also get an update on Lockheed Martin's (LMT) F-35 program. A major cybersecurity conference is ahead, and earnings reports are due from NetEase (NTES), Applied Materials (AMAT), Cisco Systems[ticker…

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is at a crossroads and should make "needle-moving" acquisitions either in data-center infrastructure, software or security, says a William Blair analyst."We do not believe the old Cisco playbook of numerous tuck-in acquisitions combined with a few larger bets in emerging product areas will work," said Jason Ader, a William Blair analyst, in a research report Monday. He maintained an outperform rating on Cisco stock, which inched down 2 cents to 31.30 on the stock market today, close to a buy point of 32.04.If Cisco "doubles down" on data-center infrastructure, Ader speculates, it could buy Nutanix (NTNX), Pure Storage (PSTG), Nimble Storage (NMBL) or NetApp (NTAP).If Cisco takes a "hard pivot" toward software, it could acquire Splunk (SPLK), Red Hat (RHT) or ServiceNow (NOW), Ader said.Cisco now garners about 5% of revenue from computer security products. It could make a big jump by purchasing Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) or Proofpoint (PFPT), Ader added."Like its large-cap peers in IT infrastructure, we believe Cisco needs to embark on a fundamental business metamorphosis," Ader said in the report.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix, Glaukos and Broadcom are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Cisco in January agreed to buy AppDynamics for $3.7 billion, just ahead of that company's planned IPO. AppDynamics provides cloud-based software that measures and analyzes the performance of business critical applications.While Cisco has a partnership with Dell-EMC on networking products,  Ader says it could "file for a full divorce."Ader says that Cisco's effort to build a cloud computing rival to Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), hasn't clicked. "Its much-hyped, $1 billion Intercloud cloud-federation project launched in 2015 is expected to be shuttered shortly — likely another casualty of AWS," wrote Ader.The Trump administration has proposed a one-time tax cut for the repatriation of U.S. companies' corporate profits held overseas, which could provide Cisco with more ammunition to make acquisitions, says the William Blair analyst."We believe the company needs to place needle-moving M&A bets with a clear strategic objective, instead of its current (incremental) approach," he wrote.RELATED:How Cisco's AppDynamics Buy Could Impact New Relic, Splunk, IBM, HPE

F5 Networks (FFIV) and Akamai Technologies (AKAM) loom as potential takeover targets in 2017, say analysts who upgraded the stocks to buy.Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan upgraded Akamai stock to outperform from neutral, with a target price of 80. Jim Suva, a Citigroup analyst, upgraded F5 Networks to buy from neutral and hiked his price target to 175 from 143."We see F5 Networks, Electronics for Imaging (EFII), NetApp (NTAP) and Benchmark Electronics (BHE) as potential M&A targets," said Suva in his research report Wednesday.F5 Networks stock had jumped nearly 47% to 142.40 in 2016 as of Tuesday, well extended from its last buy point of 125.01 touched in July. Shares of F5 Networks have traded well above its 50-day moving average since its last earnings report, in late October.IBD'S TAKE: Both F5 Networks and Akamai belong to IBD's Internet-Network Solutions group, which is ranked No. 134 out of 197 industry groups.  Gigamon, which had been the group's leader, has dropped out of the IBD 50, where chip maker Nvidia is the top-rated stock.Akamai's stock has climbed 19% in 2016 through Tuesday, despite slowing revenue and EPS growth. The stock has been forming a flat base, with a buy point of 71.14.Akamai closed 2.8% higher at 66.99 in the stock market today. F5 rose 1.2% to end at 144.08."Akamai has done a good job diversifying into cloud security and we believe that high 30% growth for the product category is achievable over the next couple of years," said Horan in his research report.Cambridge, Mass.-based Akamai's CDN (content delivery network) services increase the speed of e-commerce transactions, business software downloads and video streaming to mobile devices."Akamai  could also be a viable acquisition target for any company looking to create unique/highly secure cloud capabilities, but we do not believe it is for sale," Horan wrote. "We believe Akamai would be a great fit for Microsoft (MSFT), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Oracle (ORCL) and many other companies looking to break into the cloud services space."Suva rates F5 Networks as Citigroup's "top stock pick in IT hardware." "We shift Cisco Systems lower, still maintaining a buy rating, given the (potential) tax benefits from Trump administration" Suva said in a report.Seattle-based F5 Networks is the leading maker of application delivery controllers (ADCs) — electronic boxes that direct data traffic to computer servers. ADCs optimize server workloads in corporate and telecom data centers, helping speed up websites and communication networks.RELATED: Akamai Security Business Shines, Offsets Apple, Facebook ShiftAT&T Swallows Razor-Thin Margins On $35 Video Streaming DealF5 Networks Upgraded, Price Target Hiked On Fiscal Q4 Beat

Data management systems giant NetApp (NTAP), amid a tough transition to the cloud, late Wednesday gave current-quarter guidance solidly above Wall Street estimates, sending shares gapping up to a 20-month high.For the current fiscal Q3 ending Jan. 27, the company expects earnings per share minus items of 72-77 cents, where analyst consensus had been just 65 cents, according to Thomson Reuters. It sees revenue of $1.4 billion at the midpoint of its guidance, where analyst consensus had been $1.36 billion.NetApp stock jumped 6.3% in the stock market today to 36.90 and easily popping above a buy point of 36.20 out of a consolidation. Earlier, shares rose as much as 12% to 39, their highest point since February 2015.The company's fiscal Q2 ended Oct. 28 was a mixed bag, however. EPS ex items of 60 cents, down 2% from the year-earlier quarter, easily beat the 54-cent consensus, but sales of $1.34 billion, down 7%, missed by $20 million. It marked the 12th straight quarter of year-over-year sales declines. EPS has fallen in six of the past seven quarters.IBD'S TAKE: Which companies are hitting 52-week highs? That easy to find at IBD's New Highs, but that list goes one big step better. That is, it ranks the companies making new highs by Composite Rating. So the best are at the top, making this a quick and easy read to find stocks for your watch list.Drexel Hamilton upgraded its rating on NetApp stock to buy from hold, and at least three investment banks hiked their price targets, RBC and Baird to 40 and BMO to 39. In raising his price target from 36, RBC analyst Amit Daryanini said "we think NTAP's ability to streamline its cost structure while positioning the company for (year-over-year) growth through mix shift toward strategic marks an encouraging step toward revenue/margin stabilization following volatile financial performance in recent years."But many analysts remained cautious. William Blair's Jason Ader maintained an underperform rating on NetApp stock, and expects much more competition from Dell Technologies (DVMT), the recently merged Dell-EMC. Flash-storage firm Pure Storage (PSTG), a 2015 IPO, is among its other rivals."While NetApp is managing expenses well, product gross margin continues to be challenged, and we see significant execution risks ahead as competition intensifies in all-flash storage, cloud-based and hyperconverged alternatives encroach on the traditional storage market, and macro and IT spending environment continue to be constrained," Ader wrote in his research report. "We believe Dell-EMC in particular could be a thorn in NetApp's side in calendar 2017 as the dust settles on their merger and the company goes into attack mode (we believe NetApp is likely benefiting from merger-related disruptions at present.)"Pacific Crest's Alex Kurtz maintained a sector weight rating. He said the decline in NetApp's legacy business might have bottomed out, though, and says prospects will improve if NetApp can maintain its momentum in moving more customers to its flash/cloud clustered ONTAP data management software.NetApp this month announced a 6% workforce reduction, following a large round of layoffs in February, as it tries to convert to the cloud."Our second-quarter results are evidence of our ability to maintain a high level of execution while streamlining the business and pivoting to the growth areas of the market," company CEO George Kurian said in the earnings release. "Our market-leading innovations in flash, next-generation data centers and hybrid cloud, coupled with a sharp focus on operational discipline, position NetApp to lead in the digital era."RELATED:NetApp Near Buy Zone Ahead Of Earnings

Stocks were mixed early Thursday as the market digested earnings reports, economic data and comments from Fed chief Janet Yellen, who said ahead of her Congress testimony a rate hike would be "appropriate relatively soon."The Nasdaq and S&P 500 added 0.1%, but the Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.1%. Volume was tracking higher across the board vs. the same time Wednesday.Data storage, homebuilders and oil stocks outperformed in today's stock market action, while solar, meat products and discount retailers underperformed. West Texas intermediate oil prices surged nearly 2% to $46.39 a barrel.Chevron (CVX), Exxon Mobil (XOM), Home Depot (HD) and Microsoft (MSFT) led the upside on the Dow with gains of 1% or more.The Dow's biggest loser was Cisco Systems (CSCO), which gapped down and slumped 6%, tumbling below its 50-day moving average in massive trade.  The stock fell to the bottom of a flat base it's been working on since early September. The networking gear maker late Wednesday reported better-than-expected quarterly results, but its fiscal Q2 outlook disappointed.Wal-Mart (WMT) also weighed on the blue chip index, falling 3% and slicing its 50-day and 200-day lines in heavy volume. The world's biggest retailer reported mixed Q3 results; the midpoint of its Q4 and full-year profit guidance came in below the consensus forecast. Shares remain within flat-base range.NetApp (NTAP) gapped up and soared 10%, clearing a 36.20 buy point of a cup base in fast trade to its best levels since January 2015. The data storage company late Wednesday reported fiscal Q2 earnings that beat estimates and guided its current-quarter EPS above views. Drexel Hamilton raised its rating to buy from hold; a flurry of other analysts lifted their price targets.In economic news, consumer prices rose 0.4% in October, in line with views and up slightly from September's 0.3% increase. Initial unemployment claims fell 7% to 235,000 in the week ended Nov. 12, well below views for 257,000 claims. Meantime, October housing starts jumped to an annualized rate of 1.323 million, vs. projections for 1.168 million and September's upwardly revised 1.054 million starts. Building permits also topped views.RELATED:Cisco Guidance Misses, CEO Blames 'Wait And See' Telecoms Post-Trump Fed's Yellen: Rate Hike 'Appropriate Relatively Soon'; Delay RiskyMicrosoft, Time Warner, NetApp Upgraded; Cisco PT Sliced

NetApp (NTAP) turned in mixed results but gave strong guidance, while Cisco (CSCO) and L Brands (LB) beat views but were cautious on their forecasts. First Solar (FSLR) warned earnings could vanish in fiscal 2017.Estimates: Fiscal Q2 EPS ex items up 11% to 54 cents, with sales of the data-storage systems giant down 6.2% to $1.36 billion.Results: EPS of 60 cents, on revenue of $1.34 billion.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 72-77 cents, above consensus for 65 cents, on revenue of $1.325 billion-$1.475 billion, with the midpoint above Wall Street views for $1.36 billion.Stock: Shares soared 10% after hours.NetApp this month announced a 6% workforce reduction, following a large round of layoffs in February, as it tries to convert to the cloud.Estimates: Fiscal Q1 EPS flat at 59 cents on revenue of $12.332 billion, down 2.8%. Part of the sales decline stems from Cisco's sale of its set-top box business in 2015.Results: EPS of 61 cents on revenue of $12.35 billion.Outlook: Q2 EPS of 55-57 cents, below views for 59 cents, with revenue down 2%-4%, while analysts see a 1.8% increase.Stock: Shares dropped 4% late in the stock market today.The maker of computer networking gear has been shedding staff in an attempt to focus more on cloud-based services and software, and away from the routers and switches that built the company's reputation but have shown weakness recently.RELATED:Juniper Will Do Better Vs. Cisco, Arista, Says Goldman SachsCisco Systems Earnings Focus: Expanding Profit MarginsCisco Rival Arista Networks Beats On Earnings, Sales, GuidanceEstimates: Q3 EPS down 27% to 40 cents, with revenue up 3% to $2.559 billion.Results: EPS of 42 cents on revenue of $2.58 billion, with comp sales up 2%.Outlook: Q4 EPS of $1.85-$2.00, below consensus for $2.03.Stock: Shares were down 2% late.The parent of Victoria's Secret has tried to put more effort toward its international prospects and selling products directly to consumers, rather than through retail outlets, Credit Suisse said in a research note this month."However, the company, which already has 3,000 stores and 10 million square feet of real estate in the U.S. continues to emphasize square footage growth in North America as a key component of the growth strategy going forwards," analyst Christian Buss said in that note."We view this as a big risk that relies too much on the health of a declining U.S. mall environment, particularly in lower-tier malls."The solar power company announced an acceleration in certain production lines and related workforce reductions, prompting updates to its guidance.Outlook for 2016: Adjusted EPS now seen at $4.60-$4.80, above views for $4.46, up from a prior forecast for $4.30-$4.50.Outlook for 2017: Breakeven to an adjusted profit of 50 cents a share, well below consensus for $1.94.Stock: Shares sank 11% late after a temporary trading halt.

Stocks opened mildly higher Thursday, following a raft of positive jobs and housing market data and ahead of this morning's testimony by Fed chief Janet Yellen before Congress.The Dow industrials and Nasdaq rose 0.1% while the S&P 500 added 0.2%.The stock market today will have all ears on comments from and questions asked of Chairwoman Yellen by Congress, scheduled for a 10 a.m. ET start. It will be the Fed chair's first visit to Capitol Hill since the election of Donald Trump as president and the affirmation of the Republican majority in the House and Senate, with the questioning expected to be rigorous.Meanwhile, New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley is scheduled to speak before a conference in New York at 8:50 a.m. ET.Overseas trading laid low ahead of Yellen's commentary. China's markets were mixed, up and down only 0.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended flat. Benchmark indexes in Frankfurt and Paris were also mixed in a very tight range entering afternoon trade, and London's FTSE 100 added 0.2%.Earnings reports drove stocks all over the map, with retail and shipping being early centers of activity.Best Buy (BBY) leapt 6% after reporting third-quarter results. Staples (SPLS) was up a fraction.Wal-Mart (WMT) dragged 3% lower. The big box retailer's third-quarter earnings slipped less than projected by analysts. Revenue rose 1%, just shy of expectations, and midpoints for management's fourth-quarter and full-year earnings guidance were below consensus views. Wal-Mart shares are working on the right side of a possible base pattern.Cisco Systems (CSCO) dropped 6%, hurt by a fiscal first-quarter report late Wednesday that showed better-than-expected earnings and revenue, but second-quarter guidance was below consensus. Cisco has been working on building a flat base since early September.NetApp (NTAP) skipped up 10%, soaring on adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings that fell less than analysts expected. Revenue undercut expectations by a narrow margin and management offered third-quarter earnings guidance well above views and revenue in line with consensus views. The data storage specialist broke out from a cup base with a buy point of 36.20.The rally in shipping stocks continued, with Dryships (DRYS) up 58% in premarket trading but halted in regular trading. Sino Global Shipping (SINO) soared 80%. Euroseas (ESEA) spiked 25%. Aegean Marine Petroleum (ANW) hopped up 13%. Seanergy Maritime Holdings (SHIP) rose 6%.Consumer prices gained 0.4% in October, the Labor Department said, an uptick from September's 0.3% increase and in line with consensus expectations. Core prices, minus energy and food, added 0.1%, equal to the prior month's move and below views for a 0.2% increase.Initial unemployment claims slumped sharply to 235,000 in the week ended Nov. 12, down from 254,000 claims in the prior week and sharply undercutting estimates for an uptick to 257,000 claims. The four-week moving average also dipped sharply, its first decrease in five weeks.Housing starts surged to an annualized rate of 1.323 million in October, according to the Commerce Department, vs. an upwardly revised tally of 1.054 million starts in September. The number easily topped economist projections for a rate of 1.168 new starts. Building permits, which gauge upcoming activity, rose to an annualized pace of 1.229 million. That was slightly above September's rate, but well above consensus views for permits issued at a rate of 1.190 million.Manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region slowed in November, reducing the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey to 7.6, vs. a 9.7 reading in September. Economists had expected a decrease to a reading of 8.0. New orders and shipments increased, the report said, and delivery times and unfilled orders were positive, but employment categories lagged.Crude oil futures gained more than 1%, sending West Texas Intermediate back above $46 a barrel. Gold was up a fraction to just below $1,225 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the pound and the euro, but up against the yen.  Bonds eased, lifting the 10-year-yield 2 basis points to 2.25%.RELATED:Cisco Guidance Misses; CEO Blames 'Wait-And-See' Telecoms Post-TrumpFed's Yellen: Rate Hike "Appropriate Relatively Soon"

Goldman Sachs upgraded Microsoft (MSFT) to buy on upbeat views for its cloud computing business, MoffettNathanson upgraded Time Warner (TWX) on improving odds it'll be acquired by AT&T (T); NetApp's (NTAP) better-than-expected guidance won an upgrade and several price target hikes; and Cisco Systems' (CSCO) price target was lowered on a disappointing fiscal Q2 revenue outlook.Goldman Sachs upgraded Microsoft to buy from hold with a price target of 68. Heather Bellini, a Goldman analyst, says Microsoft's Azure cloud service will prosper vs. Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Alibaba Holdings (BABA)."We believe the shares are poised to more consistently outperform in the year ahead on the back of sustained traction in its cloud offerings. We estimate that Microsoft Azure will contribute $0.94, or 19% of Microsoft's total 2020 non-GAAP EPS of $4.83, and potentially $19 per share (23% of total estimated value)," Bellini said in a report.Microsoft stock rose 1.7% to 60.64 Thursday, still in buy range from a 58.80 entry area.RELATED:Apple, Microsoft, Cisco Eye Trump Overseas Cash Tax PlanAmazon Confronts Microsoft, Google, IBM In Cloud Computing WarsMoffettNathanson upgraded the media giant to buy with a price target of 100 on increasing odds that regulators will approve AT&T's $85 million purchase. Analyst Michael Nathanson says there's now a 60%-65% chance of the deal getting through, up from 50% following Donald Trump's election. MoffettNathanson's price target of 100, though, is still below AT&T's 107 per-share offer.Time Warner stock gained 2% to 90.69; shares in AT&T were up 0.7%.RELATED:AT&T Downgraded, FCC Might Also Review Time Warner AcquisitionDrexel Hamilton upgraded NetApp to buy from hold with a price target of 52. RBC Capital raised its price target on NetApp to 40 from 36; Jefferies to 38 from 34; Citigroup to 39 from 33; BMO Capital Markets to 39 from 31; and Piper Jaffray to 37 from 31.Late Wednesday, NetApp reported fiscal Q2 profit minus items of 60 cents, down a penny vs. a year earlier but above analysts estimate of 54 cents. NetApp guided January quarter EPS to a range of 72-77 cents vs. consensus estimates of 65 cents.Shares jumped 6.25% to 36.90 after hitting 39 intraday.RELATED:NetApp, Two Other Stocks Clear Buy Points, Hit New HighsDrexel Hamilton sliced its price target on Cisco to 36 from 37; RBC Capital lowered its price target to 34 from 35. Cisco late Wednesday reported fiscal Q1 earnings and revenue that topped views but forecast current-quarter profit and sales below expectations. CEO Charles Robbins blamed weaker demand from telecom companies for the disappointing revenue outlook.Cisco stock fell 4.8% to 30.05.RELATED:Cisco Guidance Misses, CEO Blames 'Wait And See' Telecoms Post-TrumpIn other analyst moves, Dougherty & Co. initiated iRobot (IRBT) at buy with a PT of 65; iRobot has an IBD Composite Rating of 92. BTIG Research initiated Adobe Systems (ADBE) with a neutral rating and started Shopify (SHOP) (IBD) at buy. BTIG also initiated ChannelAdvisor (ECOM) at neutral.

Tech stocks were in the driver's seat again for the third straight session Thursday as Wall Street weighed strong housing data, more earnings reports and comments from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen.However, data networking gear stalwart Cisco Systems (CSCO) and retailing giant Wal-Mart (WMT) lagged in the Dow after reporting earnings. Cisco slumped nearly 6% and Wal-Mart gave back 3%.Nasdaq 100 component NetApp (NTAP) gapped up over a 36.20 buy point but gave back early gains. Shares still rose 7% after the maker of network storage and data management hardware reported better-than-expected earnings late Wednesday.The Nasdaq composite added 0.5%, the S&P 500 rose 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average was mostly unchanged. Volume on the Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Wednesday's level in the stock market today. NYSE volume was on pace to be slightly lower.In economic news, U.S. new-home construction jumped to a nine-year high in October, weekly jobless claims dropped 19,000 to 235,000, a sign that the U.S. labor market is getting tighter. Economists expected a small increase to 257,000.Meanwhile, in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Yellen reinforced expectations of a rate hike at the Dec. 14 meeting. Currently, futures traders think there's a 90% chance of it happening, according to data from the CME Group.Among the day's movers, consumer electronics retailer Best Buy (BBY) gapped up over a 40.31 buy point, jumping 13% to 45.70. The stock opened at 42.93 and was in buying range for awhile but not anymore. A big earnings beat was the catalyst, helped by strong sales of televisions and related home theater products, mobile phones, wearables and connected home devices.MaxLinear (MXL) outperformed in the IBD 50, rising 4% to 22.15. It's still in buy range from a 21.52 cup-with-handle buy point. Nvidia (NVDA) also did well with a nearly 2% gain. Shares soared 30% last week on strong earnings, but the stock is close to moving above an upper channel line which would be a sell signal for those with a big profit in the stock. Elsewhere, Middleby (MIDD) continued work on the right side of a base as shares rose around 3%. The stock is working on its sixth straight gain after reporting earnings last week. Earnings growth has averaged 32% over the past four quarters. Sales growth has averaged 28% over the same time period. Middleby  makes commercial food service, food processing, and residential kitchen equipment.After the close, watch for earnings results from Applied Materials (AMAT) and Ross Stores (ROST). Applied Materials is working on a shallow, cup-shaped base with a 31.17 buy point. Shares were recently trading around 30.55. Ross Stores' flat base currently shows a 66.38 buy point. Shares were recently trading around 66.38.December WTI crude oil futures were recently trading around $45.28 a barrel, down 0.6%. The 10-year Treasury yield added 5 basis points to 2.27%.RELATED:Fed's Yellen: Rate Hike 'Soon,' Will Serve Full TermEconomy Gets A Thumbs Up On Jobs, Homes, Factories And InflationHow Much Would A Six-Month Cut In OPEC Output Actually Help Oil?Are We Approaching The Dawn Of A Secular New Bull Market?
