Analysts raised price targets for Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOGL), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Costco (COST) Friday, while NetApp (NTAP) got an upgrade, and Guggenheim Securities started coverage on a host of retailers, including Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT).The analyst battle over iPhone demand took another turn as Citigroup's Jim Suva boosted his price target for Apple to 130 from 120, while raising his fourth-quarter sales forecast to 79.4 million units vs. a consensus of 75 million. Suva maintained a buy rating, saying that iPhone 7 demand has been limited by supply, with some stores only receiving enough to fill preorders.A day earlier, Apple lost its Top Pick status at Barclays, with analyst Mark Moskowitz citing risk of sales "petering out" and cutting his target for overall smartphone market unit growth.Apple shares rose 0.8% to close at 113.05 on the stock market today.RBC Capital analyst Mark Mahaney raised his price target for Google's parent to 1025 from 1000, keeping an outperform rating. He sees concerns about slowing growth at Google as overdone, pointing to YouTube's $10 billion run rate with 30%-40% growth.Alphabet shares edged up 0.2% to 804.06.Cowen boosted its price target for the wireless technology firm to 74 from 62, keeping a buy rating. Amid reports that Qualcomm is in talks to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), analyst Tim Arcuri touted the potential combination, saying it would give the company exposure to the automotive and industrial markets and increase its leverage "in defining the 5G ecosystem."Arcuri also sees Broadcom (AVGO) as a potential bidder for NXP, but sees Xilinx (XLNX) as a better deal for Broadcom.Qualcomm shares rose 1.6% to 68.50 Friday, after a 6.3% spike on Thursday.Summit Redstone analyst Srini Nandury boosted his rating on the storage and data management company to buy from sell, hiking his price target to 45 from 30. Nadury came away from a NetApp user conference convinced that the company is on the right track after discussions with customers and partners.Shares dipped 3.1% to 35.82 on Thursday, breaking out into buy territory.IBD'S TAKE: Visit IBD University for a primer on timing stock purchases to maximize your chances of success.RBC Capital bumped up its price target for warehouse club retailer Costco to 178 from 177, keeping an outperform rating. After the close on Thursday, Costco reported better-than-expected earnings, but fell short of revenue targets.Guggenheim Securities called Amazon "our best idea," giving it a buy rating and a 950 target. The firm also gave Wal-Mart a buy rating and an 82 target. KeyBanc started Wal-Mart with an overweight rating and 90 target, saying the Jet.com acquisition solidifies its No. 2 position in e-commerce.Costco shares rose 3.4% to 152.51. Amazon rose 1% to 837.31. Wal-Mart rose 2% to 72.12.

Enterprise data-storage company NetApp (NTAP) reported quarterly earnings after the market close Wednesday that beat on the top and bottom lines, as did forward-looking estimates, sending the stock up sharply to a nine-month high in heavy volume.NetApp has experienced multiple quarters of year-over-year declines in earnings and revenue as the company undergoes a product transition in a challenging market.NetApp reported revenue of $1.29 billion, down 3% year over year but just above Wall Street estimates of $1.26 billion. In 10 out of the last 11 quarters, NetApp has posted year-over-year revenue declines.Excluding one-time items, NetApp reported earnings per share of 46 cents, topping the consensus of 36 cents, for its fiscal first quarter ended July 29. EPS rose 59%, reversing five quarters in a row of EPS declines. It was the best gain since fiscal Q1 2011.NetApp stock surged 17.4% to 33.88 on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: NetApp stock on Thursday broke a nearly 20-month long downtrend, representing a very significant change in character and honing in on a 52-week high of 34.81 set on Oct. 23. The stock would hit a buy point at 34.91. NetApp drove its 16-company Computer-Data Storage group to a seven-month high, but it still ranks a lowly No. 162. It's a good idea to track IBD's 197 Industry Groups daily.For its fiscal Q2, NetApp expects revenue in the range of $1.265 billion to $1.415 billion, slightly above the consensus of $1.35 billion at the midpoint. That would be down 7% year over year.It expects earnings minus items in the range of 51 cents to 56 cents. The consensus is 54 cents."We believe it is fair to say that NetApp has slowed the decline in its overall business through a focus on strategic solutions and significant restructuring actions," wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research note. He rates NetApp stock a hold."This intentional shift in the business mix has been ongoing for many quarters now, but the headwinds from the legacy business appear to be diminishing (somewhat)," Kugele wrote.Srini Nandury, an analyst at Summit Redstone Partners, maintained a sell rating on NetApp stock, but he expects to re-evaluate that at after an industry conference later this month.Still, Nandury upped his price target on NetApp to 30 from 20 "to reflect the recent multiple expansion across the tech landscape," he wrote."The storage industry remains in turmoil with pricing pressures, migration of some workloads to cloud, and NetApp-specific product transition issues," Nandury wrote. "We are cautiously optimistic the worst is behind for the company, and we believe NetApp can grow its product revenue from the current levels during fiscal 2017."In the company's earnings conference call, NetApp CEO George Kurian said the product transition is beginning to change the trajectory of its business."We are clearly making progress but still have work to do as we operate in a low-growth macroeconomic and IT spending environment," he said. "We are controlling what we can and are increasingly confident in our ability to execute as we streamline the business and pivot to the growth areas of the market."

Three leading stocks cleared buy points en route to new highs Monday as the major averages finished little changed. NetApp (NTAP), a maker of network storage and data management hardware, on Monday tried to build on last week's 22% rally following a strong quarterly earnings report. The stock cleared a 34.91 buy point of a cup base in heavy volume…

Cisco Systems (CSCO), NetApp (NTAP) and L Brands (LB) and NetEase (NTES) topped quarterly reports after Wednesday's market close.Estimates: Analysts expect the networking gear giant to report a 1.7% rise in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings per share to 60 cents with revenue down 2% to $12.57 billion.Results: EPS of 63 cents on revenue of $12.64 billionOutlook: Q1 EPS of 58-60 cents, vs. consensus for 60 cents, with adjusted revenue falling 1% or rising 1%. Wall Street sees a 1.6% decline.Cisco is restructuring to eliminate up to 5,500 positions and plans to reinvest in security, Internet of Things, the cloud and data centers.Shares dipped 0.4% after hours on the stock market today.RELATED:Estimates: Consensus is for the network storage and data management equipment maker to record a 24% increase in fiscal Q1 EPS to 36 cents on a 5.7% drop in revenue to $1.26 billion.Results: EPS of 46 cents on revenue of $1.29 billion.Outlook: Q2 EPS of 51-56 cents, vs. consensus for 54 cents, on revenue of $1.265 billion-$1.415 billion, vs. consensus for $1.33 billion.Shares rallied 7% after hours.Estimates: The parent of Bath Body Works and Victoria's Secret is projected to report a 13% decline in Q2 EPS to 59 cents. Revenue is forecast for a 3.5% rise to $2.86 billion.Results: EPS of 70 cents on revenue of $2.89 billion. Comp sales rose 3%.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 40-45 cents, vs. consensus for 47 cents. Full-year EPS view raised to $3.85 from $3.70, vs. consensus for $3.74.Shares climbed 1.6% after hours.Estimates: Wall Street expects China-based online gaming company's Q2 EPS to rise 61% in local currency to $2.61. Revenue is seen rising 81% in local currency to $1.26 billion.Results: GAAP EPS was $3.10, non-GAAP EPS was $3.67.  Revenue was 8.9528 billion yuan ($1.347 billion), up 96% in local currency.Revenue rose 76% in online game services, 24.2% in advertising services, and 310.6% in e-mail, e-commerce and other business.Shares rose 2.7% in late trading.RELATED:

Kinder Morgan (KMI) received a rating upgrade Thursday, while Twitter (TWTR) was downgraded, and Target (TGT) had its price target cut. Cisco (CSCO) and NetApp (NTAP) had their price targets raised.Morgan Stanley upgraded Kinder Morgan to overweight, with a 24 price target.Last week, fund manager Appaloosa said it cut its stake in Kinder Morgan by 66.7% to 1.5 million shares.Shares rose 4.4% to 22.71 on the stock market today. The stock broke out of a flat base last month and is now out of buy range.IBD'S TAKE: EOG Resources, Diamondback Energy and others in the oil patch are ripe for buying, as oil prices continue to rise above $40 per barrel. Twitter was downgraded to sell from hold at Evercore ISI, citing increased competition in social media, especially from Snapchat. On Tuesday, Twitter announced a way of turning users' photos into ads via "promoted stickers."Credit Suisse also said Snapchat is grabbing ad dollars from Twitter.Twitter shares fell 5.8% to 19.RELATED:Twitter Unveils 'Quality Filter' As Analyst Sees Snapchat ThreatCisco had its price target raised to 30 from 28 at Morgan Stanley and to 25 from 24 at Credit Suisse, with both targets still below the current stock price.Cisco reported fourth-quarter earnings above analyst estimates late Wednesday, but sales were hit by weakness in China. The computer networking leader also said it will slash 5,500 positions, or about 7% of its workforce, starting this quarter.Cisco shares fell 0.8% to 30.48.Susquehanna raised its price target on NetApp to 36 from 25.Late Wednesday, the network storage and data management equipment maker reported Q1 earnings above analysts' estimates, but revenue was light. Looking ahead to Q2, NetApp sees EPS of 51-56 cents, vs. a consensus projection of 54 cents, on revenue of $1.265 billion-$1.415 billion, vs. consensus for $1.33 billion.Shares jumped 17.4% to 33.88, approaching a 34.91 buy point.RELATED:Target's price target was lowered to 82 from 88 at Telsey Advisory.On Wednesday, the retailer reported Q2 EPS that beat Wall Street estimates, but sales were down 7%, missing views. Same-store sales fell 1.1%.Target said it's lowering its earnings expectations for the year to $4.80-$5.20 a share, down from a prior outlook of $5.20-$5.40. Analysts now expect $5.04 per share.Shares dipped 0.5% to 70.30.RELATED:

Stocks opened quietly Thursday as the dollar continued lower, with the market looking toward more comments from the Federal Reserve later in the day.The Dow industrials, Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 each eased less than 0.1% lower. The Russell 2000, which lost 0.3% on Wednesday, inched slightly higher.Wal-Mart (WMT) rumbled more than 2% higher to 74.69 after reporting a smaller-than-expected slip in its second-quarter earnings, along with a slight revenue beat and an increase in its full-year earnings guidance.NetApp (NTAP) snapped more than 12% higher. The maker of data center gear reported after Wednesday's close that its earnings rose for the first time in seven quarters.However, China-based online gaming provider NetEase (NTES) slid more than 5% to 201.05 despite reporting late Wednesday an 89% jump in earnings and an 83% revenue increase, topping analyst expectations. The IBD 50 stock ended Wednesday's session extended after clearing a cup-with-handle buy point at the end of June. It had triggered the 20% sell rule earlier in the week ahead of the quarterly results.Acacia Communications (ACIA), also an IBD 50 stock, rose 2% to 117.39, striking new highs. The new IPO and high-speed network components maker ended Wednesday thoroughly extended, up 20% so far this week and with a 77% gain since the start of August.Japan's Line (LN) backtracked as much as 4%, cooling off after running higher for nearly three weeks. The Leaderboard stock was up 8% for the week as of Wednesday, and it sports a 29% gain since the start of August. It broke out Monday past a 44.59 buy point from a base that followed its initial offering on July 14.Agilent Technologies (A) dropped more than 4% and is testing support at the 50-day moving average after its fiscal Q3 report late Wednesday showed earnings above and revenue equal to analysts' targets. But management's Q3 earnings and revenue guidance was below expectations.New unemployment claims slowed to 262,000 in the week ended Aug. 13, the Labor Department said. That was down from the prior week's 266,000 claims and below views for 265,000. The four-week moving average rose to 265,250 -- a third straight increase.Growth in mid-Atlantic manufacturing was "positive, but tenuous" in August, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve reported. Its Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey earned a 2.0 reading for the month, better than July's minus 2.9 tally and in line with consensus expectations. Indicators for current orders and employment were generally weak, but respondent forecasts of future activity "showed notable improvement."At 10 a.m. ET, New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley has scheduled a press briefing. Dudley stirred the market on Tuesday, with comments that a Fed rate hike could come as soon as September. Minutes from the Fed's July 27 meeting released Wednesday contradicted that view.Also at 10 a.m. ET, the Conference Board reports its July leading economic indicators index.In oil, West Texas Intermediate futures climbed 1% to top $47 a barrel, up 6% so far for the week. Brent crude reversed an early dip and added a fraction to trade just pennies below the $50 mark. Gold added a half percent to $1,355 an ounce. The dollar turned mixed, up vs. the yen, but down against the euro and the pound, holding near seven-week lows after two days of whipsaw action. Bonds inched up, trimming the 10-year Treasury yield 1 basis point to 1.54%.Overseas markets were mixed. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index climbed 1%, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 1.6%. In Europe, benchmark indexes in London, Paris and Frankfurt traded flat to narrowly higher in early afternoon action.

Stocks ended slightly higher Wednesday after Federal Reserve policymakers were split on the need for an interest-rate hike. Cisco Systems (CSCO) dipped 1% after the close, while NetApp (TAP) jumped 5% after reporting earnings.The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1% and the Nasdaq ended up a fraction. Volume in the stock market today was higher across the board, according to preliminary data.Stocks erased mild gains in the afternoon, after minutes from the Fed's July 27 meeting showed policymakers had greater confidence in the economic outlook, but remained reluctant to raise interest rates.Computer networking giant Cisco Systems was down about 1% after the close despite reporting higher-than-expected profit and sales for the fiscal fourth quarter that ended in July. The stock dipped 1% during the regular session, ending just below a 52-week high. It was reported that Cisco plans to lay off 14,000 workers or about 20% of its global workforce.Agilent Technologies (A), a maker of scientific measuring instruments, fell 5% after the close following its quarterly results.NetApp (NTAP) jumped more than 5% in post-session trading after the maker of network storage and data management hardware posted better-than-expected fiscal Q1 profit and sales.The stock is working on a long and deep cup-type base.Chinese social networking stock YY (YY) was up 3% after the close after its Q2 results. The stock has retaken its 10-week moving average but is hitting resistance at its 40-week line as it tries to recover from a long slide.Retail stocks were hardest hit during the regular session, following disappointing earnings reports.Lowe's (LOW) dropped more than 5% after the home improvement retailer reported that profit for the fiscal second quarter that ended in July rose 9% to $1.31 a share, below Wall Street expectations.Sales edged up 5% to $18.3 billion, also below views.But L Brands (LB) popped 3% in post-session trading after the parent of Bath & Body Works and Victoria's Secret posted better-than-expected Q2 profit and sales. The company also raised its full-year profit outlook.Ross Stores (ROST), Applied Materials (AMAT), Toro (TTC) and Foot Locker (FL) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic data due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Aug. 13, the Philadelphia Fed's index of mid-Atlantic manufacturing for August and The Conference Board's Index of Leading Economic Indicators for July.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is likely to make more software- and security-related acquisitions, based on what the computer networking firm said at its Cisco Live customer conference July 10-14, according to a new research report from RBC Capital."While Cisco did not provide financial updates, comments and partnerships announced (at Cisco Live) suggest that the company is laser focused on expanding its recurring revenue streams and de-emphasizing legacy routing/switching in the future," RBC analyst Mitch Steves wrote."We think Cisco's strategy remains sound, and we believe future M&A and partnerships will continue to focus on software/security transactions," Steves said.IBD's TAKE: Cisco stock has traded between 24 and 31 for the past 18 months, but it's one of the most followed tech stocks and ranks third in the IBD Computer-Networking industry group -- facts you can learn at IBD Stock Checkup.Some analysts have speculated Cisco could buy a data storage company such as NetApp (NTAP) to better position itself vs. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE).Cisco Systems stock is up 10% in 2016. Cisco stock ticked up 0.3% to 29.91 at the close on the stock market today. The company is scheduled to report its July-quarter earnings on Aug. 17. Chuck Robbins took over as Cisco's chief executive last July, replacing longtime CEO John Chambers.At the customer conference, Cisco showcased a partnership with startup SwiftStack, the RBC analyst said."On the storage side, Cisco is partnering with SwiftStack to create a model similar to Amazon Web Services (part of Amazon.com (AMZN)) on the storage space," said Steves.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) could go shopping for a data storage company with software expertise, as enterprise customers shift toward “converged infrastructure,” says Barclays.While Cisco has a joint venture with EMC (EMC) and alliances with NetApp (NTAP) and startup SimpliVity, the computer networking giant needs to own data storage assets as customers shift to converged data center infrastructure -- including servers -- that run on network management software, the investment bank said.“We believe converged infrastructure could be an area of interest for Cisco to tactically acquire software-defined storage assets,” Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz said in a research report.  “While storage is the glaring hole in Cisco’s portfolio, we think the company will move away from hardware-based assets as it attempts to shift to more software mix and value-added services.”Aside from Cisco, Moskowitz says Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), EMC, VMware (VMW) and Oracle (ORCL) aim to be players in the converged infrastructure market. EMC is in the final stages of  being acquired by privately held Dell.“Hyper-converged infrastructure relies more on software and seems to be ushering in the software defined data center. As such, consolidation may be critical for some of the systems-centric vendors to keep pace with innovation within the software realm,” he wrote.San Jose, Calif.-based Nutanix has been gaining share in converged infrastructure, says the Barclays report. Nutanix might well rekindle plans for an initial public offering, analysts say.Hewlett Packard Enterprise, meanwhile, also is on the prowl for acquisitions, according to analysts.“Converged infrastructure is just a way of packaging IT components to drive efficiencies rather than a radically different concept that unlocks incremental revenue,” said Moskowitz. “We think storage vendors get hurt the most, implying only upstarts or companies not possessing legacy storage like Cisco are best positioned to benefit from this trend.”Cisco stock fell 0.65% to 28.84 in the stock market today. HPE lost 2.7% and EMC dipped 0.1%.

Stocks rose sharply for a second session Wednesday as oil prices neared $50 a barrel, bolstering sentiment that the economy is strong enough to withstand higher interest rates.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.8%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq each climbed 0.7%. Volume was mixed, slipping on the Nasdaq while rising modestly on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.After the close, NetApp (NTAP) plunged 8% after the maker of data-storage systems issued a disappointing fiscal Q4 earnings report.  Profit for the period fell 15% to 55 cents a share, the fifth straight decline and below Wall Street expectations. Sales fell 10% to $1.38 billion, the sixth straight decline and also worse than expected.Williams-Sonoma (WSM) rose nearly 4% in post-session trading after the home-furnishings retailer released its quarterly earnings report. HP (HPQ) was up about 1% following mixed quarterly results.Oil, retail and bank stocks were among the best performers during the regular session in the stock market today, while defensive utility names were among the biggest decliners.Western Alliance Bancorp (WAL) jumped nearly 3%, clearing a 37.58 buy point of a cup-with-handle base in heavy volume. The Phoenix-based regional lender has posted three straight quarters of accelerating profit growth. Revenue growth has been strong over the past three quarters.Oil driller Transocean (RIG),  up nearly 10%, was the best performer in the S&P 500 as oil prices jumped 2% to just below $50 a barrel on a drop in inventories.The Federal Reserve has hinted at an interest-rate hike at its next meeting in June, as long as the economy continues to pick up. Higher oil prices could signal higher interest rates to the extent that they reflect rising global demand.Most IBD 50 stocks rose. Dycom Industries (DY) rocketed more than 13%, breaking out past a 73.28 buy point of a cup-with-handle base, after the telecom infrastructure company reported better-than-expected quarterly results.

Pure Storage (PSTG) received an upbeat review ahead of its first-quarter earnings report next week, with an analyst saying the flash storage market appears to be growing faster than expected.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin said Pure Storage appears to be gaining market share at the expense of legacy storage vendors including IBM (IBM), NetApp (NTAP) and EMC, which Dell is acquiring.“Reseller and partner feedback during March and April suggests demand for flash remains strong, particularly for Pure Storage,” Bracelin wrote in a research note.Pure Storage makes storage products based on flash chips, designed for the business enterprise market. Flash-based storage arrays are much faster than disk-drive storage systems but generally come at a higher price. Flash is seen as the future of storage, with that transition well underway but still in the early stages.The vast majority of the storage spend is still with the largest incumbents, including NetApp, IBM and EMC. Pure Storage is growing fast, but it's still incurring large losses.Pure Storage continues to invest heavily to support a business model that is on pace to quickly scale to a $1 billion run-rate within five years after shipping its first product, Bracelin wrote. The company has $604 million in cash and no debt, and it remains on track to reach positive cash flow by the end of 2018, he said."We estimate Pure's revenue could grow by 60%-plus this year, driven by flash share gains,” Bracelin wrote.Pure Storage is set to report earnings after the market close Wednesday, for its fiscal Q1 ended April 30.The Wall Street consensus estimate on revenue is $138 million, up 86% year over year. The bottom-line consensus, as polled by Thomson Reuters, is for a per-share loss minus items of 23 cents, vs. a 26-cent loss in the year-earlier quarter.Pacific Crest continues to rate Pure Storage stock overweight, or buy, "based on the promising potential to build a next-generation storage franchise, strong balance sheet with over $600 million in cash, and the longer-term profit potential,” Bracelin wrote.Bracelin has a price target on Pure Storage stock of 24. The company came public in October 2015, raising $425 million with an initial public offering that priced 25 million shares at 17.Pure Storage stock was near 14.50, up 1%, in afternoon trading in the stock market today.

HP Inc. (HPQ), Williams-Sonoma (WSM), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF), NetApp (NTAP) and PVH (PVH) reported earnings after the close Wednesday, while highly rated WebMD (WBMD) announced a convertible debt offering.HP reported 41 cents fiscal Q2 EPS, 2 cents above the same quarter a year before. Revenue of $11.6 billion was down 11% from $13 billion a year earlier, prior to the split up of Hewlett-Packard. Analysts expected EPS of 38 cents on $11.72 billion in revenue.Personal Systems revenue fell 10% to $6.99 billion. Printing net revenue slid 16% to $4.64 billion. For Q3, HP sees EPS of 37-40 cents, below consensus for 41 cents.Shares fell 1.6% late, after closing up 2.4% at 12.20 in regular trading.The other Hewlett-Packard spin-off, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), on Tuesday reported strong first-quarter results and announced plans to spin off its Enterprise Services Business prior to its merging with Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC). Hewlett Packard Enterprise rose 6.8% Wednesday, and CSC soared 42%.The media and entertainment company's Q4 EPS fell 50% to 7 cents a share, but this surprised analysts who on average expected a 2-cent per-share loss.Revenue rose 22.5% to $791.2 million, well above consensus for $738.7 million, "due to record television revenue and increased theatrical box office from five wide releases, compared to three wide releases in the prior year quarter."Shares jumped 13% late.Households goods purveyor Williams-Sonoma's Q1 earnings grew 10% to 53 cents a share on 6.5% revenue growth to $1.1 billion, topping estimates for EPS of 50 cents on $1.078 billion in revenue.For Q2, the company sees EPS of 54-60 cents on $1.145 billion-$1.175 billion in revenue vs. current estimates for EPS of 59 cents and $1.171 billion in sales.For the year, Williams-Sonoma sees EPS of $3.50-$3.65 and $5.15 billion-$5.25 billion in revenue vs. views for $3.55 EPS and $5.21 billion in sales.Shares rallied 3% after closing up 2.4%.Apparel maker PVH (PVH) said its Q1 EPS minus items was $1.50, unchanged from a year earlier and beating estimates by 7 cents a share. Revenue grew 2.1% to $1.918 billion, topping views for $1.898 billion, on 4% higher sales of Tommy Hilfiger and a 13% increase for its Calvin Klein line.PVH sees full-year diluted EPS of $6.45-$6.55, topping consensus for $6.46. Shares rose 8% in extended trading after closing up 1% at 89.83.NetApp reported fiscal Q4 EPS of 55 cents on revenue of $1.38 billion. Analysts had expected NetApp to report 58 cents on sales of $1.4 billion. The data storage vendor guided Q1 EPS below views. NetApp increased its quarterly dividend by a penny to 19 cents a share, but shares fell almost 8% late.WebMD fell 3.5% in late trade. WebMD, the online health information site, announced plans to offer $300 million of convertible debt in a private offering.

Stock futures held on to early gains on the approach to Wednesday’s open, after a strong session Tuesday gave a bullish twist to several weeks of sluggish market action.Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures each traded 0.5% above fair value. Dow industrials futures added 0.4%.The Commerce Department reported the U.S. trade deficit widened in March to $57.5 billion, an increase of nearly $2 billion over February's gap. Economists had projected a wider spread of $60.2 billion.Housing prices gained a better-than-expected 0.7% in March, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency. Its Housing Price Index rose 0.7% for the month vs. views for a 0.5% increase. Year-over-year, the index is up 6.1%.Researcher Markit delivers its preliminary estimate for April services sector performance at 9:45 a.m. ET. Dallas Federal Reserve President Robert Kaplan is scheduled to speak at 1 p.m.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) soared 13% in premarket moves, and Computer Sciences Corp. (CSC) zoomed 31% higher, after HP reported Q2 results and announced it would divest its enterprise services business to CSC. HP Inc. (HPQ), the old Hewlett-Packard hardware and outsourcing business, reports results after today's close.Retail stocks leaned toward another tough start on the stock market today, however, with Express (EXPR) down 18% and Tiffany (TIF) off more than 3% after delivering their first-quarter results.Telecom construction firm Dycom (DY) swept up 12% in premarket action after its fiscal Q3 revenue and earnings topped analyst targets by broad margins. Management also ratcheted up its fourth-quarter sales and EPS guidance to well above consensus views. The IBD 50 stock ended Tuesday just below a 73.28 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Alibaba Group Holdings (BABA) came under some pressure, dipping nearly 3%, after the China-based e-commerce giant reported it was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. A company filing said the investigation, which is looking into reporting related to its Singles Day sales vent and other issues, was initiated earlier this year.Overseas, stocks in Europe advanced, adding to early gains in midday trade. The CAC 40 in Paris and the DAX in Frankfurt each traded up more than 1%. China’s markets were sharply mixed after the central bank set its lowest peg for the yuan since 2011. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng index popped 2.7%, but the Shanghai composite eased 0.2%.  In Japan, Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 surged 1.6%.Oil prices trimmed early gains to just below 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate at $49 per barrel and up 6% for the week. Gold slipped less than 1% to $1,223 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the yen and down vs. the euro, while bonds held effectively flat.In addition to HP Inc., today's busy after-hours session includes reports from Infoblox (BLOX), NetApp (NTAP) and Lions Gate Films (LGF), as well as a string of retail and apparel names such as Costco (COST), PVH (PVH), Guess (GES) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM).

Cowen & Co. upgraded Microsoft (MSFT) to outperform Tuesday on an upbeat view of its Office subscription business, while MoffettNathanson downgraded Twitter (TWTR) to sell on "advertiser fatigue," and Pivotal Research Group raised its price target on Charter Communications (CHTR).Cowen says Microsoft's transitioning Office into subscription product has been overlooked, adding that its survey of 300 cloud computing users also bodes well for Microsoft's Azure service."We are confident that Office revenue will accelerate further in fiscal 2018," the Cowen report said.Cowen maintained a price target of 58 on Microsoft. Cowen also downgraded VMware (VMW) to neutral and upgraded Western Digital (WDC) to outperform.Microsoft shares were up 3.1% at the close on the stock market today. VMware rose 1.2%, and Western Digital surged 4.5%.MoffettNathanson downgraded Twitter to sell from neutral. Twitter’s management shake-up has yet to turn around the company, says analyst Michael Nathanson.“Twitter is now not only dealing with user fatigue, but advertiser fatigue as well,” said Nathanson in a report. “The path forward will not get any easier as Twitter increasingly competes with Instagram, Snapchat, Pinterest, core Facebook (FB) and YouTube.”Twitter shares ended the day down 2.6%.Pivotal Research Group raised its price target on Charter to 285 from 250. Charter recently closed its acquisitions of Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, morphing into the No. 2 cable TV firm behind Comcast (CMCSA).John Malone's Liberty Broadband (LBRDA) is the biggest shareholder of Charter.Charter shares added 1.5%.Topeka Capital Markets initiated coverage on Bed Bath and Beyond (BBBY) and Lumber Liquidators (LL) with sell ratings. Topeka started coverage on Tempur Sealy International (TPX), Culp (CFL) and Big Lots (BIG) with hold ratings.Credit Suisse initiated coverage on Callon Petroleum (CPE), an oil and gas exploration company, with a buy rating and a price target of 14. Callon Petroleum has an IBD Composite Rating of 79.In other analyst moves, Chardan Capital initiated coverage on Sage Therapeutics (SAGE) with a sell rating. RBC Capital upgraded Forward Air (FWRD) to outperform with a price target of 52 and lowered NetApp's (NTAP)  target to 26. BMO Capital Markets upgraded Deere & Co. (DE) to outperform with a target of 96.

Make room for IBM (IBM) as well as the usual suspects -- Amazon Web Services, Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet’s Google --  in the cloud computing market hierarchy, UBS says in a research report.While AWS, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), and Google (GOOGL) are strongest in infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), Microsoft’s Azure service and IBM are formidable in platform-as-a-service (PaaS), according to the UBS survey of corporate information technology executives.In the IaaS market, customers rent computers and data storage via the Internet. In PaaS, companies sell applications and software, including business management and database services, that run on cloud infrastructure.“Cloud is not a winner-take-all market,” said UBS. “We believe the 'big will get bigger,' ... AWS, Microsoft, and Google are going to be winners, with IBM holding its own."The likely losers, based on UBS estimates of revenue exposure, include Rackspace (RAX), Nimble (NMBL), Pure Storage (PSTG), Brocade (BRCD), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), and NetApp (NTAP).”Rackspace, which is set to report Q1 earnings after the close Monday, is transitioning to a services model, providing support for AWS and Azure.IBM acquired IaaS provider Softlayer in 2013. To be stronger in PaaS, IBM has layered software on Softlayer’s infrastructure and made other cloud acquisitions, says UBS.One surprise in the UBS survey is that IT executives expect pricing for cloud computing to moderate. Some analysts predict Google will be more aggressive in cutting prices.

No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) will cut 12,000 jobs by mid-2017, and that will help kick off a "recession" with nearly 400,000 tech positions to be cut this year, a Global Equities Research analyst predicted Tuesday.Late Tuesday, Intel added another domino to the layoff train, joining VMware (VMW), Yahoo (YHOO), BlackBerry (BBRY), Autodesk (ADSK) and NetApp (NTAP), which recently announced plans to collectively lay off 5,125 employees.Intel's 12,000-cut represents 11% of its global workforce. Global Equities Research analyst Trip Chowdhry says it's just a drop in a 369,000 bucket (his prediction for tech layoffs that will be announced this year) and argued against a Federal Reserve rate increase amid what he calls a likely oncoming recession.On Wednesday, Wall Street was largely split on Intel's mixed Q1, with at least five analysts still rating Intel stock a buy. At least two analysts cut their price targets, however, and another downgraded Intel stock.In early afternoon trading on the stock market today, Intel stock was up 1.5%, near 32. But shares are down 8% for the year vs. a 3% decline in IBD's 39-company Electronic-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group.For Q1 ended April 2, Intel reported $13.7 billion in sales and 54 cents earnings per share, up a respective 7% and 20% year over year. The consensus of 45 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected $13.8 billion and 48 cents.PC chip sales rose 2%, but that trailed stronger growth in data center, Internet of Things and security -- up a respective 9%, 22% and 12%. Nonvolatile memory chip sales fell 6%.Current-quarter sales guidance for $13.5 billion, plus or minus $500 million, lagged the consensus for $14.2 billion. Intel's April quarter benefited from an extra week.Intel's transition from a PC-oriented company will be "messy," Credit Suisse analyst John Pitzer wrote in a research report. Late Tuesday, CEO Brian Krzanich said the layoffs would allow Intel to save $750 million in the first year and $1.4 billion per year starting by mid-2017, so that the company can "intensify" investments in key growth areas.Pitzer reiterated an outperform rating and a 40 price target on Intel stock.PCs represented 55% of Intel's Q1 sales vs. 58% a year earlier. In 2011, the client computing group accounted for 65% of Intel's revenue. The company is aiming to trim that to 50%, which Semiconductors Advisers President Robert Maire calls a "milestone.""Intel is certainly trying, perhaps with varying degrees of success, to get revenue from many other markets," Maire wrote in a research report. "While individually, none hold a candle to the PC market, collectively they have been a great offset."Unlike other companies, Intel isn't in the red while transitioning, Maire noted. He likened the restructuring -- which includes transitioning CFO Stacy Smith into a role leading sales, manufacturing and operations -- to teaching an elephant to dance.The elephant theme was popular Wednesday. "Who says elephants can't dance?" Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan queried in a report. Sundararajan reiterated his buy rating and 37 price target on Intel stock."Keeping (2016) capital expenditures the same ($9.5 billion at the midpoint) while proceeding with a layoff confirms that Intel is trying to be more nimble and refocusing itself away from the PC," he wrote in a report.During Q2, Intel will recognize a $1.2 billion restructuring charge. But the second half of 2016 looks promising, Sundararajan said. Intel dropped full-year guidance to mid-single-digit growth vs. earlier views for mid- to high-single-digit growth.Sundararajan says this suggests a big second-half-year recovery, with revenue up 13%.

Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) both got higher price targets Monday, while Walt Disney (DIS) was upgraded, Citigroup (C) was downgraded and ebay (EBAY) got a lower price target.Credit Suisse raised its price target on Facebook to 142 from 140 and maintained its outperform rating on the stock.Last week, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg unveiled his 10-year plan for the social media giant, including ways to enhance connectivity, power experiences and transactions with artificial intelligence.Facebook shares closed up 0.7% on the stock market today.Google parent Alphabet had its price target raised to 920 from 900 by Credit Suisse, which rates the stock an outperform. Early Monday, News Corp. (NWS) expanded its antitrust complaint against Google amid an investigation by EU regulators into Google’s Android mobile-phone operating system.Alphabet stock rose 1% to about 787.68, extending a recent breakout. Alphabet reports earnings on Thursday.Walt Disney shares rose 2.9% after it was upgraded to buy at Pivotal Research, which put a 121 price target on the stock.Disney’s "The Jungle Book" generated $103.6 million in North America over the weekend to place it among the biggest April debuts ever at the box office.Citigroup rose 0.4% despite getting a downgrade to market perform from outperform at Keefe Bruyette & Woods, which maintained its 51 price target on the stock.On Friday, the banking giant beat quarterly profit views but also logged weak trading and investment banking revenue.EBay’s price target was lowered to 28 from 29 at Credit Suisse, which maintained its neutral rating on the stock. Shares rose 0.4%.NetApp (NTAP) was downgraded to underperform at Sterne Agee CRT.  NetApp fell 1.35%Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qorvo (QRVO) was initiated at market perform with a 50 price target at Cowen & Co. Even so, Qorvo shares fell 1.2%.Apple’s stock price lost 2.2% after closing down 2% on Friday, falling below its 200-day line.IBD's Take: How healthy is Apple's stock, and how does it compare to its peers? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupImage provided by Shutterstock.

Tectonic shifts to cloud computing and flash storage make the time ripe to build a new storage franchise, with Pure Storage (PSTG) seen as an industry disruptor.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Brent Bracelin, in a new research note, says that Pure Storage has been able to sustain solid growth and market share gains despite legacy vendors such as EMC (EMC) and NetApp (NTAP) putting Pure Storage in their cross hairs.Bracelin’s report came as Pure Storage introduced several new products on Monday that expand its portfolio of storage systems, including products that integrate more tightly with server gear from Cisco Systems (CSCO).Pure Storage provides the $24 billion enterprise storage market with technology using flash chips, similar to the chips that smartphones use. Flash-based storage arrays are much faster than disk-drive storage systems but come at a higher price, depending on how the technology is deployed. Flash is seen as the future of storage, with the transition well underway but still in the early stages.“We believe these new products, coupled with continued declines in flash pricing to less than $1 per GB, should give Pure Storage the ammunition to sustain share-gain momentum into 2016,” Bracelin wrote.EMC and NetApp lead in the disk-storage systems market and also have expanded into flash-chip storage systems. NetApp and EMC, which Dell is acquiring, are much larger than Pure Storage, but the smaller company is growing much faster. It has yet to turn a profit, however.Pure Storage revenue has zoomed from $6 million in 2013 to $440 million for its fiscal 2016 ended Jan. 31. But the company has posted big losses as it spends heavily on research and development and on marketing to grow market share.Pure Storage kept its string of triple-digit revenue growth alive on March 2, when it posted fourth-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street estimates, as did its Q1 outlook.Company CEO Scott Dietzen says that the data storage industry is on the cusp of a revolutionary change that Pure aims to lead. But a recent report from Summit Research said that while Pure Storage has cutting-edge data technology, it will face an uphill battle trying to dislodge EMC and NetApp.Bracelin has an overweight rating on Pure Storage stock and a price target of 24.Pure Storage stock was near 12.50, in midday trading on the stock market today  -- down 3% despite the bullish research note. Pure raised $425 million with its initial public offering on Oct. 7, pricing shares at 17. The stock peaked at 20.60 on Oct. 15 and hit a low of 11.05 on Feb 8.“While execution risks remain elevated as legacy vendors attempt to grab share by discounting storage pricing, a solid track record of execution since the October 2015 IPO increases our confidence that Pure Storage can sustain solid momentum and share gains,” Bracelin wrote.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Apple (AAPL), IBM, and Cisco Systems (CSCO) have higher earnings quality than some 3D printer makers, based on their GAAP vs. non-GAAP accounting, says UBS.Tech companies, and some others, typically report both non-GAAP  earnings -- which exclude stock options grants to employees and often other items -- and earnings under GAAP (generally accepted accounted principles), which include everything. Financial analysts typically provide non-GAAP estimates for quarterly results, and those numbers frequently get more play in quarterly earnings stories in the business press.“Non-tech investors sometimes recoil at the liberal non-GAAP reporting by tech companies and its acceptance by investors,” noted UBS analyst Steven Milunovich in the research report. Milunovich says a large difference between GAAP and non-GAAP earnings should be taken into account in assessing a stock's price-to-earnings, or P/E, ratios.“Apple's financial statements embody the same user-friendly nature as its products in only reporting GAAP numbers," he wrote.Milunovich also said the GAAP to non-GAAP EPS difference for IBM (IBM) is just "modest," and is a "relatively conservative" 12% for Cisco.IBM is slated to report its Q1 earnings on April 18, and Apple on April 25.IBM stock fell 0.3% to 152.07 on the stock market today. Apple rose 1% to 111.12, closing just below Apple's 200-day line after the stock topped that key level intraday for the first time in 2016.Milunovich is the second tech analyst in a week to take a close look at GAAP vs. non-GAAP earnings. Citigroup analyst Mark May last week slashed his price target on LinkedIn (LNKD)  and also lowered its targets on shares of Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and Netflix (NFLX) in a report that examined the earnings dilution from stock compensation grants.Milunovich says restructuring charges also impact GAAP vs. non-GAAP accounting.The UBS analysts flagged the leading makers of 3D printers. He said that in 2015 “both Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD) had large impairments, especially Stratasys' write-off of MakerBot, creating the biggest gaps (in GAAP vs. non-GAAP accounting)” among the companies he looked at. Storage vendors including Nimble (NMBL), NetApp (NTAP) and EMC (EMC) also had relatively large differences in GAAP vs. non-GAAP earnings, he wrote.

Stocks dipped narrowly at Monday's open, then quickly improved to mixed action as oil, mining and some retail stocks all posted early gains.The Dow rose 0.4% as Wal-Mart (WMT) and DuPont (DD) gained more than 2% each. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq slipped 0.3% apiece.The stock market today had opened to mixed trade, with volume rising 2% on the Nasdaq and dipping 8% on the NYSE, compared with action at the same time Friday.About a third of the Dow industrials' stocks rose at the starting bell. DuPont kept its premarket lead, up almost 3%, as takeover speculation continued to make the rounds. Pfizer (PFE) and Nike (NKE) slumped lower, down 0.9% and 0.8%, respectively.Nine of the S&P 500's 10 largest gains were from energy and oil stocks. The tenth was a 3% gain from NetApp (NTAP). The data storage heavyweight rallied for four straight weeks through Friday. On Monday, shares traded 28% above a Feb. 12 low.Losses among S&P 500 stocks were moderate. Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) took the hardest hit, down about 1.5% after Bank of America downgraded shares to neutral from buy.Iron ore was a focal point of the morning after spiking 19% overnight on global markets -- a record one-day surge. Ore miners posted the best gains on the London Stock Exchange, although London's FTSE 100 traded down 0.8% in afternoon trade. New York-listed shares of Vale (VALE) surged 9% at the start of trade on U.S. markets. Rio Tinto (RIO) jumped more than 3%, and BHP Billiton (BHP) rose more than 2%.Among leaders, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) pared losses but was still down more than 5% in early trade. The stock recovered to almost 4% above a 24.64 buy point after clearing a two-month cup base Friday.

Pure Storage (PSTG) kept its string of triple-digit revenue growth alive and posted fourth-quarter earnings after the close Wednesday that beat Wall Street estimates, as did its Q1 outlook.Pure Storage reported revenue of $150.2 million, up 128% from the year-earlier quarter and soundly beating the consensus estimate of $138.6 million. It was the ninth quarter in a row of triple-digit gains.The company reported a per-share loss minus items of 12 cents, vs. the consensus estimate for a 16-cent loss, as polled by Thomson Reuters, for the period ended Jan. 31.Pure Storage stock, which rose 5% to 15.71 in regular trading, was up another 5% in after-hours trading, after the company released its earnings.For Q1, Pure Storage forecast revenue of $135 million to $139 million, above the $130.5 million analyst consensus. For the year, Pure Storage expects revenue of $685 million to $725 million. The consensus is $667 million."We delivered our best ever quarter in Q4, concluding another record setting year for Pure Storage," company CEO Scott Dietzen said in the earnings release. "The business continues to run on all cylinders, fueled by the rapid worldwide adoption of FlashArray combined with improved operating efficiency as we scale."The company grew its customer base by more than 120% over the past year to more than 1,650 organizations, it said.Pure Storage provides flash-chip-based storage systems for the enterprise market, a cutting-edge technology that is making life difficult for storage leaders EMC (EMC) and NetApp (NTAP).CEO Dietzen says that the data storage industry is on the cusp of a revolutionary change that Pure aims to lead. But a recent report from Summit Research said that while Pure Storage has cutting-edge data technology, it will face an uphill battle trying to dislodge EMC and NetApp.

Pure Storage (PSTG) stock was up for the fifth day in a row ahead of its fourth-quarter earnings set for release today after the close.Pure Storage is a provider of flash-chip-based storage systems for the enterprise market, a cutting-edge technology that is making life difficult for storage leaders EMC (EMC)and NetApp (NTAP).Pure Storage CEO Scott Dietzen says the data storage industry is on the cusp of a revolutionary change that it aims to lead. He says Pure Storage is one of the fastest-growing tech companies in history. The Mountain View, Calif.-based company launched its first product in May 2012 and has posted triple-digit revenue growth for at least eight quarters in a row.Make that nine, if Pure Storage holds onto its brisk revenue-growth pace.The consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters call for Q4 revenue of $138.6 million, up 110% from the year-earlier quarter. But that rapid growth has come at a cost, as Pure Storage is pouring big sums into sales and marketing, and research and development, in an aggressive bid to expand market share.The company is expected to post a loss of 16 cents a share, compared with a 25-cent loss last Q4.Pure Storage stock was up 1.2%, near 15, in afternoon trading in the stock market today, and Wednesday touched its 2016 high. Pure Storage made its initial public offering in October, raising $425 million by pricing 25 million shares at 17.A recent report from Summit Research said that while Pure Storage has cutting-edge data technology, it will face an uphill battle trying to dislodge EMC and NetApp.EMC on Feb. 29 announced new products that it called “a quantum leap in flash storage.” EMC said it will commit to all-flash for its primary storage offerings, "relegating traditional disk to bulk and archive storage requirements." In October, EMC has agreed to be acquired by Dell for $67 billion, a deal that is not yet completed.In December, NetApp announced that it will pay $870 million in cash to acquire SolidFire, a provider of storage systems that are based on flash-memory chips.

Amazon (AMZN) and IBM (IBM) got upgrades Thursday while price targets on Marvell Technology (MRVL) and Brocade Communications  (BRCD) were raised. Canaccord Genuity upped Amazon to buy with a price target of 750 as the e-commerce giant announced it would open a fulfillment center in Britain to further expand its European business. Amazon is reportedly looking to expand its…

A Marvell Technology (MRVL) patent settlement, a Chinese takeover of Ingram Micro (IM), NetApp (NTAP) layoffs and weak Jack in the Box (JACK) earnings moved those stocks in after-hours action Wednesday.Ending litigation that started in 2009, Marvell Technology agreed to pay $750 million to settle a patent infringement lawsuit filed by Carnegie Mellon University over disk drive technology.The settlement was announced six months after a federal appellate court vacated a record $1.5 billion judgment against Marvell and ordered a new trial. But the court also ruled that Marvell must pay at least $278.4 million in damages.A federal jury in Pittsburgh had awarded Carnegie Mellon $1.17 billion in damages in 2012. The trial judge later raised that total to $1.5 billion, reflecting Marvell's alleged willful infringement plus interest.A "substantial share" of the $750 million settlement will go to the inventors of the disputed technology, minus legal fees and costs, Carnegie Mellon said.Marvell shares rose more than 6% after hours.China-based Tianjin Tianhai Investment will pay $38.90 a share, or $6 billion, for Irvine, Calif.-based information technology company Ingram Micro.Ingram Micro stock soared 24% after hours when news of the deal broke.Tianjin Tianhai is a unit of Chinese shipping and aviation conglomerate HNA Group. Some of Ingram Micro's customers include Apple (AAPL) and Cisco Systems (CSCO).The offer represents a 31% premium on Ingram Micro's closing price of 29.65 on Wednesday.McDonald's (MCD) launch of its all-day breakfast menu hurt Jack in the Box during the latter's fiscal first quarter, sending its shares plunging nearly 20% after hours.For the three-month period ended Jan. 17, the San Diego-based fast food restaurant chain earned 93 cents a share, flat from a year earlier and 10 cents below estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 0.5% to $470.8 million, missing estimates of $475.5 million."We believe a competitor's messaging around its launch of all-day breakfast had some impact on our results, particularly in the 10:30 a.m. to noon period," Jack in the Box Chairman and CEO Lenny Comma said in a statement.McDonald's launched its all-day breakfast menu during Q4, which helped the Oak Brook, Ill.-based fast food giant post its best U.S. quarterly sales in nearly four years.Same-store sales at Jack in the Box's subsidiary Qdoba rose 1.5% at company-owned locations, less than previous projections of 2%. That's despite rival Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) reporting plunging Q4 and January same-store sales due to food-borne illness scandals.Jack in the Box narrowed its full-year earnings guidance to  $3.50 to $3.63 a share, compared with the previous range of $3.55 to $3.70 a share.The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based data-storage company announced a plan to axe 12% of its workforce, or nearly 1,200 workers, as NetApp aims to cut $400 million in costs.NetApp estimated that it will book between $60 million and $70 million in costs tied to the layoffs during its fiscal Q4.For its fiscal Q3, the three-month period ended Jan. 29, NetApp earned 70 cents a share excluding items, down 6.7% from a year earlier, and beating by 2 cents estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 10.6% to $1.4 billion, missing estimates of $1.5 billion.NetApp also gave light Q4 guidance.But NetApp stock rose 2% late.

The data storage industry is on the cusp of a revolutionary change that Pure Storage aims to lead. Pure Storage (PSTG) is a provider of data storage systems, for business and other enterprise users, that are based on a chip technology known as flash — similar to chips used in smartphones. Industry observers expect storage systems based entirely on flash chips will ultimately replace systems based on high-performance disk drives, with Internet cloud-based storage growing much faster than on-site storage.The leaders in the disk-storage systems market are EMC (EMC) and NetApp (NTAP), companies that also have expanded into flash-chip storage systems. NetApp and EMC, which is being acquired by Dell, are much larger than Pure Storage, but the smaller company is growing much faster. It has yet to turn profitable, however.For its fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 31, Pure Storage reported revenue of $131.4 million, up 167% from the year-earlier period, and an operating loss of $55.6 million.Mountain View, Calif.-based Pure Storage, which raised $425 million in an initial public offering in October, is looking to disrupt EMC and NetApp, among others.Scott Dietzen, Pure Storage CEO, recently spoke with IBD about the company's plans.IBD: How has cloud computing changed storage requirements for the business enterprise?Dietzen: Cloud computing is disrupting the storage business because most of the legacy storage is very expensive, very complicated and it doesn't fit well into cloud data centers. And then you have flash memory, which is poised to replace all of the fast, high-performance disks drives in data centers. It's a double tsunami hitting the storage industry.IBD: How is Pure Storage disrupting the storage industry?Dietzen: If you look at the storage industry before Pure entered the market, most of the technology in use today is more than 20 years old. It was designed far in advance of cloud computing and was designed in advance of flash memory.We came to market and said there is an opportunity to deliver storage that actually costs less to buy and is at least 10 times better in every dimension that businesses care about. It's 10 times faster, it's 10 times denser, it's 10 times more power efficient, and it's way more than 10 times reliable. Flash is 50 times more reliable than a mechanical disk. This collection of innovation in software, in hardware, in harnessing the cloud computing model and changing the business model — that combination completely changes the storage landscape. All of the legacy technology will be replaced with brand new technology.IBD: When did flash storage become less expensive than disk drive technology for enterprise storage systems?Dietzen: When Pure launched (2009), flash cost about four times more than a fast disk, and that's why we worked very hard on the data reduction technology, to get the acquisition price below that of a disk storage array. We are in the situation today where flash is dramatically cheaper than fast disks.When we started back in 2011, we were already below the price of an EMC Vmax disk array, the flagship disk array system. Since then, the cost of flash has dropped four times faster than the cost of the fast disks. We are in a situation where the consumer-grade flash we use is less than the price of fast disks and we get a 10-fold reduction in power, space and management. And we've moved to a cloud business model. We are in this situation where the $24 billion market for performance-intensive storage, in our calculus, is going to go to flash storage over the next refresh cycle or two, over the next seven or eight years.IBD: You are saying if I compare an EMC disk storage system to a Pure Storage system of similar capacity, that you will be cheaper?Dietzen: Yes, cheaper to buy and dramatically cheaper to operate. And as further evidence that the Pure disruption is carrying the day here, EMC has bought two (flash-storage system) companies — XtremIO and DSSD. Their intent, we believe, is they are going to try to replace all of their existing tier-one disk storage with flash products.And the No. 2 company in the market, NetApp, just made a similar acquisition ($870 million to buy SolidFire). If we weren't right in saying none of the technology from the disk drive era is going to make the leap to flash, then why do you have the Nos. 1 and 2 storage vendors in the market spending a lot of their dollars on trying to buy disruptors in order to compete with Pure?IBD: Some analysts say Pure Storage will face an uphill battle with EMC and NetApp, which they say will pass you by in flash storage.Dietzen: We think EMC and NetApp have hurdles in front of them. Keep in mind that changing out from an existing EMC technology like Vmax, which is the market share leader, and replacing that with ExtremIO, is an extremely disruptive change. And companies do not embrace that kind of change without looking at the newest technologies.We just have to be in the mix and get a chance to prove out the difference in our product. We beat EMC 70% of the time vs. XtremIO. We are confident that we are looking at a two-year technology lead over any of the large incumbents in the marketplace.IBD: What will happen two years from now if they catch up to you?Dietzen: We have been able to attract the best and brightest from Silicon Valley. Our goal and our belief is that our lead is growing. When we can hire the best engineers, we are able to do things that other companies can't achieve. Pure is changing the business model, we're changing all of the technology. These large incumbents are only just beginning to transition their installed base. It's extremely hard when you have 20-year-old incumbent technology and you are trying to look after that business and get disrupted at the same time. We think we have the right recipe to ultimately build the leading share in this market.IBD: When will Pure Storage reach profitability?Dietzen: We're investing heavily in R&D and also in sales, marketing and our partnering organization. The largest component of our investment is to drive growth. We are at a $500 million revenue run rate and growing at 167% year over year. At the same time, the operating efficiency of the business has been improving dramatically. We have more than $500 million in the bank. Our business is growing really fast, while we are getting more efficient at the same time. Our investors want us to capture this market. We are playing for No. 1 in a $24 billion market. We don't want to miss the opportunity and cede that long-term leadership position.

It thus caused Summit Research to initiate coverage on the upstart with a hold rating. Pure Storage provides the business enterprise market with storage products based on flash-chip technology. Analysts raised price targets on Amazon (AMZN), Nike (NKE) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) early Monday.Footwear powerhouse Nike, which is now trading at a two-for-one split-adjusted price, got its price target upped from 75 to 77 by Argus Research while D.A. Davidson put its PT on Nike at 78, with a buy rating.Last week, Nike reported fiscal Q2 earnings that topped views and indicated strong growth in futures orders, but margin guidance concerned some analysts.Nike shares closed up 1% on the stock market today.Axiom Capital upped Amazon's PT from 727 to 797 as the e-commerce company reported a record-shattering holiday season for Amazon Prime shipments and Amazon Original series' viewings.Amazon shares rose 1.9%.Axiom also upped Alphabet's PT from 900 to 1000 and reiterated a buy on the stock following reports last week that Google is developing a new mobile messenger service using artificial intelligence and looking into building self-driving cars with Ford (F) and possibly other automakers.Alphabet climbed 2.1%.In other analyst reports out early Monday, Credit Suisse maintained an outperform rating on commercial aircraft leasing company Air Lease (AL), with a PT of 45. Shares moved up 1%.Lake Street cut its PT on data-storage company NetApp (NTAP) from 36 to 32. Shares rose 0.2%.Cable TV and educational content company Discovery Communications (DISCA) got its PT cut from 39 to 38 by Topeka Capital Markets. Shares fell 0.9%Follow Marilyn Alva on Twitter @IBD_MAlva.

Here's a quick rundown of Monday's after-hours action: Steelcase (SCS) said third-quarter adjusted earnings rose a penny to 30 cents, missing by 2 cents. Revenue fell 1.6% to $787.6 million dollars, missing. Steelcase's Q4 outlook was weak. The office furniture maker's shares plunged 20% in extended trading.Cintas (CTAS) said second-quarter adjusted EPS rose 20% to $1.03, beating by 3 cents. Revenue grew 9% to $1.22 billion, in line. The uniform rental firm's full-year earnings guidance was light while its revenue outlook was in line with estimates. Shares rose 1% late.NetApp (NTAP) is buying flash-storage systems maker SolidFire for $870 million dollars in cash. The deal is expected to close in the network storage hardware maker's fiscal fourth quarter, which ends in April.And Pfizer (PFE) said its phase 3 study of Pristiq, a medication for pediatric patients with Major Depressive Disorder, did not meet its primary objective to demonstrate superior effectiveness versus the placebo. Shares still rose a fraction late.

JPMorgan Chase downgraded Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) to neutral Tuesday after another bout of E. Coli cases was linked to restaurants in Kansas, North Dakota and Oklahoma. Shares closed down 5.25% on the stock market today to a 19-month low of 494.61. The stock tumbled 3.5% on Monday. Apple's (AAPL) price target was lowered from 135 to 130 by Cowen,…
Stocks stepped into narrow gains in weak trade Tuesday, holding their ground despite a weak reading on existing-home sales in November. The Dow Jones industrial average stuck with a 0.2% gain.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 held up 0.1% gains apiece. Sellers appeared to be focusing on the small caps, sending the Russell 2000 down 0.2%.
Volume sagged 16% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq relative to activity at the same time Monday.
A slight downgrade to the Commerce Department's Q3 GDP growth estimate was in line with expectations, but may have helped place some early pressure on the stock market today.

Housing price growth slowed, but not quite as much as expected, in October, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency's Housing Price Index. It rose 0.5% for the month, down from a 0.8% increase in September but better than estimates for 0.4% growth.

Existing-home sales slowed sharply to an annualized rate of 4.76 million in November, the National Association of Realtors said. The group also revised October's sales rate lower to 5.32 million. Consensus estimates had projected a pace of 5.32 million homes sold in November.

In stocks, Nike (NKE) jumped to the front of the Dow with a 1.3% gain. The athleticwear maker reports fiscal second-quarter results after today's close. Chevron (CVX) took the index's worst decline, down 0.9%
NetApp (NTAP) tumbled more than 7% as a pair of analyst downgrades followed the announcement late Monday that it would acquire flash memory gear maker SolidFire for $870 million.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) shed 4% at the open. The Centers for Disease Control said on Monday it was investigating an additional outbreak of E.coli contamination that could be linked to the fast-casual food chain. JPMorgan downgraded the stock to neutral in a note declaring the CDC's newest investigation gives "rational and informed customers" cause to think twice before choosing to eat at Chipotle. The stock is down 34% from an October high.

Marriott International (MAR) and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) each popped 3% at the start of trade. Marriott filed S-4 registration documents related to the proposed $12.2 billion acquisition of Starwood announced in November. Marriott also said it would begin share repurchases immediately, projecting a total of $2.2 billion in share purchases in 2015. The stock is near lows in a consolidation begun in March.

Two-in-five IBD 50 stocks rose out of the starting gates. Gains were mild and led by China-based Alibaba (BABA),which climbed 1.7%. The stock has built a seven-week flat base with healthy support and an 86.52 buy point.
J2 Global (JCOM) also ranked high, with a 1.2% gain. The Internet-based fax, voicemail and call-service provider is testing its 10-week line of support, 5% above a 75.72 cup base buy point.

Alaska Air (ALK) fell 2.8%, the worst decline among IBD 50 stocks. Stifel downgraded the stock to hold from buy. The Internet-based fax, voicemail and call-service provider is testing its 10-week line of support, 5% above a 75.72 cup base buy point.Alaska Air (ALK) fell 2.8%, the worst decline among IBD 50 stocks. Stifel downgraded the stock to hold from buy. The stock is struggling to hold support at its 10-week moving average, just below an 80.22 buy point in a late-stage flat base.
Stock futures pulled back sharply from early highs ahead of Tuesday's open, as the Commerce Department trimmed its view of GDP growth in the third quarter.

Dow futures remained 33.4 points above fair market value, down from a 110-point gain an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures narrowed an early 31.9-point advance to 9.7 points. S&P 500 futures were up 4.2 points, down from 13 points.
Small caps took some early heat, as Russell 2000 futures reversed narrow early gains to a 1.9-point loss.
The stock market today is again poised for an early gain. Monday's early rally petered out, but with a flash of late-day buying hoisting the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 to a healthy finish.

Tuesday starts with an early dose of economic news. The Commerce Department revised its estimate of GDP growth in the third quarter lower, to 2%, from 2.1%. The change was in line with consensus projections. The slowdown reflected primarily a slowdown in private inventory investments and a slowdown in exports, the department said.
The department's price estimate held steady, with the GDP Price Index up 1.3%, also in line with expectations.

The Federal Housing Finance Agency reports its October Housing Price Index at 9 a.m. ET. At 10 a.m., the National Association of Realtors delivers November existing home sales numbers, and the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank releases its Fifth District Survey of Manufacturing Activity.

Overseas markets were mixed and moderate, both in Asia and Europe. The dollar backed off a bit. Bonds inched up. Oil prices rose, but not much: West Texas Intermediate up a dime to just below $36 a barrel. Brent crude up pennies to just above $36. Most metals traded lower, but only by fractions.
In stocks, Verizon (VZ) led the premarket Dow, up 1.4%. Apple (AAPL) was the only decliner, slipping 0.2%.

Among S&P 500 stocks, pharmacy benefit manager Express Scripts (ESRX) grabbed a 4% gain after management offered full-year 2015 earnings guidance in line with estimates, and raised 2016 guidance above consensus. The stock has built a six week flat base within a deeper consolidation.

Spirit Airlines (SAVE) whipped up a 4% gain, after an upgrade to buy from hold by Stifel. Spirit shares have gained some altitude following a mid-November low, but remain deep in a 12-month consolidation.

NetApp (NTAP) dropped more than 5% ahead of the open, after announcing it had agreed to buy flash storage gear maker SolidFire for $870 million in cash. NetApp shares have been in a deepening correction for 12 months.

Leaders were generally quiet in premarket action, with most IBD 50 stocks holding to gains or losses of less than 1%. Stocks scored solid gains for a second straight session Tuesday. The Nasdaq outperformed Monday, but blue chips were in the driver's seat Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1%, led by Caterpillar (CAT), which rose close to 5%. The S&P 500 added 0.9%, and the Nasdaq picked up 0.7%

Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in lower than Monday's light levels in the stock market today. Winners beat losers on the NYSE by more than 3-to-1. The ratio was less than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.In economic news, third-quarter GDP growth was revised slightly lower to 2% from an earlier estimate of 2.1%. Separately, existing-homes tumbled 10.5% in November to the their slowest pace since April 2014. Homebuilders lagged a bit, but were mostly unfazed by the news as the group rose 0.6%.Coal, steel and oil and gas stocks outperformed. February WTI crude oil futures settled at $36.14 a barrel, up 33 cents. The 10-year Treasury yield added 4 basis points to 2.23%.Alibaba (BABA) was the best percentage gainer in the IBD 50, rising just over 2%. After a strong rally off a low of 57.20, it's working on a flat base with an 86.52 buy point.New issue Atlassian (TEAM), a U.K.-based enterprise software firm, soared nearly 3% on its ninth day of trading as a public company. It went public Dec. 10 at 21. Shares closed Tuesday at 30.10.Nike (NKE) added nearly 2% ahead of its earnings report after the close. In early after-hours trading, shares rose another 2%. Earnings per share topped expectations but revenue of $7.7 billion was a bit light.And fast-growing small-cap BNC Bancorp (BNCN) added close to 3%. It's getting support at its 10-week moving average for the first time since breaking out of a base in early November.On the downside, NetApp (NTAP) slumped 5%. Late Monday, the storage vendor announced plans to acquire privately held SolidFire for $870 million, but in a note, William Blair analyst Jason Oder wrote the acquisition may be too little too late.Connect with Ken Shreve on Twitter and Facebook.

Storage vendor NetApp (NTAP) tanked Tuesday following the announcement it will pay $870 million in cash to acquire SolidFire. SolidFire provides businesses with storage systems that are based on flash-memory chips rather than spinning disk drives. Flash is seen as the future of storage, with that transition well underway. They are — drum roll, please: 1) Cisco Systems (CSCO) and NetApp (NTAP) 2) Cisco and FireEye (FEYE)…

Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) got a price target cut Wednesday despite this week's favorable regulatory ruling against a Tesla (TSLA) supplier, while Northrop Grumman (NOC) scored an upgrade, and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) was started with a bullish rating.Cowen cut Qualcomm's price target to 67 from 69 and maintained its outperform rating on the stock. Topeka Capital Markets also cut its price target on the Apple supplier to 52 from 61 and maintained its hold rating.On Monday, the U.S. International Trade Commission sided with Qualcomm and Samsung, upholding an earlier ruling that neither company violated Tesla chipmaker Nvidia's (NVDA) patents on graphics processing chips. Nvidia said it plans to appeal the decision.Qualcomm shares closed up 0.1% on the stock market today. Apple climbed 0.8%, Tesla rose 6% and Nvidia added 0.6%.Defense contractor Northrop Grumman rose 1% after it was upgraded to overweight from neutral by JPMorgan, which also raised its price target on the stock to 212 from 198.Recent consolidation in the defense industry has fueled speculation about whether a Northrop-Boeing (BA) merger might make sense, though the Pentagon is pushing for more power to block defense mergers and preserve competition.Boeing's stock price climbed 1% Wednesday.JPMorgan also upgraded fellow defense aerospace supplier B/E Aerospace (BEAV) to overweight from neutral. B/E shares rose 3.2%.Credit Suisse initiated coverage on a number of managed care stocks. Among the largest players, it started UnitedHealth Group at outperform with a 133 price target, Aetna (AET) at neutral with a 111 price target; and Humana (HUM) at neutral with a 185 price target.UnitedHealth rose 1%, while Aetna climbed 1.6% and Humana added 0.4%.NetApp (NTAP) tacked on 1.3% after it was initiated at underperform by JMP Securities.Solar energy company SolarCity (SCTY) popped more than 34% after its price target was raised to 65 from 55 by Roth Capital, which has a buy rating on the stock, though much of the gain Wednesday was attributed to congressional plans to extend solar tax credits.
