Take the example of storage company NetApp. Rather than deal with "exploding inboxes" overflowing with useless emails, NetApp (NTAP) uses ServiceNow's (NOW) products to…

Looking to push the legacy (i.e. old) giant tech stalwarts to use their cash piles to buy their way into faster growth, FBR analyst Daniel Ives issued a research report Thursday that praised Microsoft (MSFT) for its transition but kicked others — Cisco Systems, Oracle, IBM and Hewlett Packard — for their "treadmill approach" to expansion.And then he issued a wish-list of his top 10 tech tie-ups for 2016."It has been a choppy environment for tech players with a very bipolar IT spending backdrop," Ives said. "On the large-cap front, we have seen many changes from the HP split (into HP Inc. (HPQ) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) to the largest tech merger ever in Dell/EMC (EMC)."Dell offered $67 billion in October to buy EMC."That said, it has been a tough road for many of these traditional tech stalwarts such as Oracle (ORCL), IBM (IBM), Cisco (CSCO) and HP, as investors have gotten used to seeing lackluster growth on a quarterly basis in light of the massive secular and company-specific challenges these mature tech vendors face," Ives said."The lone bright star in this cloudy large-cap enterprise tech space has been Microsoft, which is gaining momentum into 2016, as (CEO Satya) Nadella has made some tough decisions ('ripping the Band-Aid' off Nokia, cost cutting, free Windows 10 download strategy) to put (Microsoft) on the yellow brick road to the cloud."We believe the combination of the Dell/EMC deal, Amazon (AMZN) (Web Services') laser focus on the cloud and Nadella's 'golden child' success has put more heat in the kitchen for CEOs such as (IBM CEO Ginni) Rometty, (HPE CEO Meg) Whitman, (Oracle co-CEOs Safra Catz and Mark Hurd), and (Cisco CEO Chuck) Robbins to change from their 'treadmill approach' heading into 2016 and to focus on M&A and/or organic growth initiatives."FBR's top 10 merger-and-acquisition wish list for 2016, "in no particular order," Ives said, are:• (1) Cisco and NetApp (NTAP),• (2) Cisco and FireEye (FEYE),• (3) IBM and Splunk (SPLK),• (4) IBM and Qlik Technologies (QLIK),• (5) HPE and Box (BOX),• (6) HPE and Qlik,• (7) Oracle and Verint (VRNT),• (8) Oracle and NetSuite (N),• (9) Microsoft and Imperva (IMPV), and• (10) Microsoft and Qualys (QLYS)."... we believe EMC/Dell has disrupted the landscape and will force many of these mature tech stalwarts to finally be more aggressive in 2016 instead of fretting about valuations, as they need to focus on putting fuel back in their near-empty growth tanks," Ives said.

Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock jumped as much as 8.5% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday posted fiscal Q4 revenue that beat views and guided fiscal 2016 performance better than analysts expected.Hewlett Packard Enterprise stock ended the day at 14.12, up 3.1%."Our overall opinion on HPE remains unchanged" after the earnings call, wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research report. He said the stock "already reflects an anticipated stabilization in some of its most troubled areas."He said positives include growth in large, tier-one hyperscale servers, while negatives included a decline in services revenue."Overall, the outlook for FY16 is unchanged (albeit more back-end loaded) and the stock is likely range-bound at current levels," said Kugele, who maintained a hold rating on HPE stock.Responding to those who say HPE isn't selling enough services and products in the cloud, company CEO Meg Whitman told CNBC Wednesday that spending for private cloud products — networks and data centers that businesses keep in-house, which is HPE's focus — is growing as fast as public cloud. "Most people don't understand that," she said."Yesterday, we announced that we were partnering with Microsoft (MFST) Azure to provide the public cloud," she told CNBC. "And then we have this great cloud system automation that helps you orchestrate your clouds in your data center. So if you think about where the money is spent today, interestingly, still about 85% of the spend is in traditional I.T. ... The next-biggest segment is private cloud. And the next after that is public cloud. And private and public cloud are growing at about the same rate."So we are going right to the heart of what our customers are asking. And I feel really good about our strategy and excited about the partnership that we announced yesterday with Microsoft Azure."Microsoft Azure competes with market leader Amazon Web Services, a unit of Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and others in providing public cloud services.Needham's Kugele liked the Azure partnership and the fact that HPE was "abdicating" in the public cloud sector, but he pointed out that Azure is fighting against AWS, "and ultimate success is going to be a marathon and not a sprint."New Era BeginsEnterprise is roughly half — most analysts say the more promising half — of the Nov. 1 split of the legendary 76-year-old Hewlett-Packard Co. The other half, HP Inc. (HPQ), focuses on the PC and printer businesses, and it kept the old HPQ ticker.The Q4 report was the last for the old company, which Whitman also chaired. It earned 93 cents per share minus items in its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 31, down 12%, on revenue of $25.7 billion, down 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 97 cents on $26.35 billion.Enterprise's pro forma portion of Q4 sales fell 4% to $14.1 billion but was up 3% in constant currency. Analysts were expecting Enterprise to post Q4 revenue of $13.5 billion.Enterprise reaffirmed its fiscal 2016 outlook of $1.85-$1.95 in adjusted earnings per share, with the $1.90 midpoint higher than the $1.88 estimated by analysts on revenue of $50.81 billion.Whitman told analysts in the conference call following Tuesday's earnings release that HPE "will double down on our private and managed cloud (efforts), and sunset our public cloud." Of "the move to a hybrid cloud environment ... you can expect to hear more."Needham analyst Kugele said that with HPE still on its way to 30,000 layoffs, and the service business determined to "drag its margins higher through careful contract signings, we are most focused on the storage and server opportunity for HPE. In servers, the lumpy buying pattern of tier-1 hyperscale customers helped them in the quarter but is hardly consistently reliable."Nevertheless we expect the segment to show slight growth in fiscal '16."He said storage has benefited from "aggressive pricing," but he sees more competition from rivals such as NetApp (NTAP) and Pure Storage (PSTG)."Bottom line, there are more puts and takes and caveats than investors should accept in a long thesis," Kugele wrote. "Staying on the sidelines."
After two strong up days following the Hewlett-Packard split-up, PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) fell Wednesday after getting a cautious report from UBS.

HP was down 2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 14. Its sister company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), was down 4%, also near 14. Hewlett-Packard split into HP and HPE on Sunday.
UBS analyst Steven Milunovich on Wednesday initiated coverage of HP with a neutral rating and HPE with a buy rating.
He set a 12-month price target of 15 on HP.

"Although we find the valuation and dividend yield somewhat attractive, we think the business fundamentals are likely to get worse before they get better," he said about HP. "We expect the printing margin to come under pressure and PC sales to decline albeit at a more modest rate."
In the longer term, he is optimistic about HP's prospects in encroaching on the copier market and becoming a leader in 3D printing.
HP gets about 80% of its profit from printing, mostly by selling ink, and the remaining 20% from personal computers.
On a revenue basis, printers and supplies account for 40% of sales, with PCs and workstations accounting for 60% of sales.
"Although HP Inc. is comprised of two secularly challenged businesses — printing and PCs — we do expect to see a benefit from increased focus over time," Milunovich said.
As for HPE, Milunovich sees the business improving in the near term, but has longer-term concerns. He set a price target of 18.50 on the stock.

"HPE has in its favor a combination of low valuation and positive momentum," he said. "We expect results to improve in storage, Enterprise Services, and software with stabilization in Technology Services and more modest growth in servers."
But HPE might be too hardware-centric and not sufficiently differentiated for long-term success, Milunovich said.
Barclays Favors HP Over HPE
Meanwhile, Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz favors HP over HPE. On Wednesday, he rated HP stock as equal weight with a price target of 14 and HPE as underweight with a target of 13.
Of the two stand-alone companies, HP is the more attractive, thanks to its better cash flow and yield prospects, he said.
HPE faces competition from cloud computing companies such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.
On Tuesday, Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 17. He gave HPE a rating of market perform and a price target of 16.

HP is the dominant player in printing, with about a 40% share of A4 laser printer units and a 45% share of A4 inkjet printer units. It is a close No. 2 behind Lenovo in the PC market, with about an 18% share.

"We believe that both are scale- and brand-driven businesses, and that consolidation is afoot in PCs, and appears inevitable in printing (both Lexmark (LXK) and Xerox (XRX) have recently announced that they are exploring strategic options)," Sacconaghi said. "In the near term, HP should benefit from distractions at its printing peers and No. 3 PC vendor Dell, which is in the process of attempting to swallow larger EMC (EMC)."

HPE faces a different set of challenges. He described it as "an on-premise vendor in an increasingly off-premise world." IT customers are shifting from servers and storage located on site to cloud computing resources accessed over the Internet.

"The IT spending landscape is undergoing massive changes, chief among them is the migration from on-premise infrastructure to off-premise solutions," Sacconaghi said. "Increasingly, CIOs are telling us that their priority for workloads is (software-as-a-service), (infrastructure-as-a-service), then — at last resort — on premise. This transition is affecting all traditional IT vendors, whose growth rates have stagnated."
Besides HPE, other vendors hurt by the shift include IBM (IBM), NetApp (NTAP), Cisco Systems (CSCO), Oracle (ORCL) and EMC excluding its VMware (VMW) unit, he said.
Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter https://twitter.com/ibd_pseitz.

True or false: Greed and fear look different on a stock chart.Absolutely true. Greed sends a stock rising in price. A stock drops on fear.Okay, that was easy. How about this? True or false: The speed in which a stock moves up on greed is the same as when a stock goes down on fear.If you've bought and sold growth stocks for a year or longer, you might agree that the answer is not so simple. Sometimes it's true, but most of the time it's false.When greed is widespread, a stock can roar with the force of a space shuttle at liftoff. A climax run — when a stock goes up faster in price in a few weeks than it ever has over the course of its run — shows how fast a leader can rise.But in most cases, fear causes a stock to lose its gains in far less time than it took to amass them.Why? Fear is mankind's survival tool. Imagine a fire at a packed movie house. You can bet people will rush out of the room much faster than they walked in.Some legendary investors strove to sell before investors panicked.In IBD founder and Chairman William O'Neil's "How to Make Money in Stocks," he quoted Wall Street maven Joseph Kennedy as saying: "The object is to get out while a stock is up before it has a chance to break and turn down."To maximize your profits, be mindful of how fear greases the wheels of a stock once it's topped. Review the Investor's Corner series on 22 top sell rules to lock in gains; it ran from Jan. 4 to Feb. 4 and is available in the Education section of Investors.com.NetApp (NTAP) broke out and soared 1,880% soon after the 1998 bear market ended in October that year 1 to its peak of 152.75 in October 2000. It's worth checking out just how fast it surrendered those awesome gains.The pioneer in network-attached data storage gear recovered from a huge sell-off in October 1998 and cleared a V-shaped base with a 61.35 buy point in heavy volume on Nov. 5 (chart shows split-adjusted prices). NetApp formed a new base in the summer of 1999, broke out again, sprinted for seven months and formed another deep base in the first half of 2000 2.The stock's climb took more than 23 months before it peaked. Earnings more than tripled from fiscal 1998 to 2000, ending in April each year. Sales grew 78%, 74% and 100% over the same time frame.NetApp broke out in September 2000 just as the major indexes were rolling over. But the breakout failed and the stock slid fast.NetApp fell 64% over six weeks in October and November 3, then gave up all its gains going back to November 1998 in less than 12 months 4. (Click here for the weekly chart.) As the dot-com bubble burst, NetApp's profit and sales took hits in 2001.

Wild action in the general market can affect top-rated stocks. On Wednesday, NetApp (NTAP) plunged in afternoon trade. Trading in NetApp was halted after quarterly results were leaked early. The data storage company topped expectations, but the outlook was weaker than expected. The outlook was enough to send NetApp down roughly 7% in Wednesday's session. Intraday trade in NetApp was…

After two strong up days following the Hewlett-Packard split-up, PC and printer maker HP Inc. (HPQ) fell Wednesday after getting a cautious report from UBS. HP was down 2% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 14. Its sister company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), was down 4%, also near 14. Hewlett-Packard split into HP and HPE on Sunday. UBS…

In the breakup of Hewlett-Packard, investors on Monday showed more love for the stodgy, slow-growth PC and printer business, rather than for the supposedly more attractive enterprise technology business.Shares of HP Inc. (HPQ), the personal computer and printer maker, were up more than 13% to near 14 in the stock market today. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock opened at 14.99 and was a fraction lower in afternoon trading.HP garnered several upbeat analyst reports post-split.Credit Suisse analyst Kulbinder Garcha initiated coverage of HP with an outperform rating and price target of 19. He called HP a "worthy annuity.""HP Inc. has a solid franchise and a multifaceted strategy to offset secular pressures in the printing and PC end markets," Garcha said in a report Monday. HP has "an extremely inexpensive valuation and significant cash return" potential.HP also is on track to improve the profitability of its printer unit by maximizing ink sales and expanding its commercial printer business, he said.S&P Capital IQ analyst Angelo Zino reiterated a strong buy rating on HP stock.Needham analyst Richard Kugele initiated coverage of HP with a buy rating and 14.50 price target.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani was more cautious on HP and its spinoff. He reiterated a sector perform rating on HP post-split and set a price target of 13.HP has "an attractive valuation and 4%+ dividend yield offset by secular challenges in printing and PC markets," Daryanani said in a report Monday.Meanwhile, he initiated coverage of Hewlett Packard Enterprise at sector perform, with a price target of 17.Credit Suisse's Garcha initiated coverage of HPE with a neutral rating and price target of 19."Secular challenges in the IT market (low growth rate and impact of the public cloud) create a headwind for the business," Garcha said in a report.HPE faces traditional competitors such as IBM (IBM) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), plus public cloud computing firms such as Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services.Mergers and acquisitions will be key for HPE, which has $11.5 billion of gross cash and $5.5 billion of net cash, Garcha said: "HPE has a strong balance sheet allowing for transformative M&A."Potential acquisitions include faster growth companies and current end-market positioning improvements, such as Arista Networks (ANET) and Nimble Storage (NMBL), and more legacy yet highly accretive acquisitions, such as NetApp (NTAP), Citrix Systems (CTXS) and CommVault Systems (CVLT).RELATED:HP Starts Life As A House Divided: Now The Hard PartHewlett-Packard spreading FUD over Dell-EMC merger.

A tectonic shift in computing architecture is seen creating ideal market conditions for a next-generation storage franchise, prompting Pacific Crest Securities to initiate coverage on Pure Storage (PSTG) with an overweight rating.
Pure Storage makes flash-chip-based storage arrays for the enterprise market. The company raised $425 million with an initial public offering on Oct. 6 that priced 25 million shares at 17.

Pacific Crest analyst Brent Bracelin set a price target of 24 on Pure Storage. The stock was down almost 2%, near 17 in early afternoon trading in the stock market today. Pure Storage is growing rapidly but is also incurring large losses. Bracelin estimates operating losses at Pure Storage could remain in excess of $100 million annually up to 2018, as the company is investing heavily to gain market share.

"Execution risks are high, given that there is little margin for error due to the company's high ambitions to quickly scale to a nearly $1 billion revenue run-rate in 2017," Bracelin wrote in the report. Despite the risk, "we think market conditions are ideal to build a next-generation storage franchise, warranting heavy investments in the short run."

He said the tectonic shift in computing architecture to cloud from client/server has reached a tipping point in 2015, evident by the combined $16.5 billion run-rate in cloud revenue by the two market leaders, Amazon.com (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT).

This generational shift to cloud, coupled with other architecture shifts in the data center toward flash and open-source software stacks has increased the impact to old-guard storage technology suppliers such as EMC (EMC), NetApp (NTAP) and IBM (IBM).

"This has prompted the first mega-consolidation trend in hardware infrastructure, in which EMC, the largest storage infrastructure company in the world, with 36% market share, has chosen to go private through an acquisition by Dell and Silver Lake in a deal that could be worth more than $60 billion," Bracelin wrote.
Annual sales in the external data-storage market is about $24 billion. The transition to flash-storage systems from disk-drive-based storage creates ideal conditions for a new technology titan.

"The storage industry is undergoing a major shift, with many customers phasing out legacy disk storage for higher-performance or more flexible systems, such as on-premise flash storage or cloud-based storage," Bracelin wrote, saying this creates a significant market opportunity for Pure Storage.
Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon.

But in terms of IPO buzz, that goes to Pure Storage, which provides data storage devices based on flash memory chips for the enterprise market. Sellers owned the early show on Tuesday, with stocks opening to losses that were broad and deep. The Nasdaq quickly slumped 1.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each dropped 1.3%.Volume was tightly mixed, up 8% on the NYSE and 3% lower on the Nasdaq relative to Monday's early trade.Oil and metals prices and stocks in Europe imposed an early influence on the stock market today. Oil dropped 3% on production and demand outlook fears as it pulled back from a rally on Monday. Silver and copper tumbled 3% each. Early losses worsened in Europe, with Frankfurt's DAX down 2.8% and the CAC-40 in Paris off 2.9% in afternoon action.U.S. economic news had little effect. The Federal Housing Finance Agency reported that its House Price Index rose 0.6% in July, a sharp improvement over June's 0.2% gain and better than the 0.4% increase forecast by economists. Year-over-year, the gauge put house prices up 5.8%.The Richmond Federal Reserve's monthly manufacturing survey dropped to a minus 5 reading, down from a flat showing in August and disappointing consensus views for an uptick to 3.On the Dow, 29 of 30 stocks opened lower. The holdout, McDonald's (MCD), clung to a fractional gain. United Technologies (UTX) fell furthest, down more than 2%. Nasdaq 100 stocks opened unanimously lower. Staples (SPLS) was hardest hit, down 5%. NetApp (NTAP) dropped 4%.Ore miners and steel makers got hammered, as commodities prices tumbled, sending silver and copper down 3% each.Automakers also got pounded, led by an 18% collapse in Volkswagen's (VLKAY) American depositary receipts. The Germany-based car builder dropped 17% Monday following news that it had programmed its diesel cars to falsify their U.S. emissions results.The selling spread across the industry, sending Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) down 4%, India's Tata Motors (TTM) down 7% and Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) down 3% apiece.Quarterly reports had some impact on early trade. Auto dealer chain CarMax (KMX) dropped 6%, the worst loss on the S&P 500, after reporting Q2 earnings below consensus forecasts. AutoZone (AZO) led the S&P 500, rising more than 2% on a strong fiscal fourth-quarter sales and earnings beat.On the IBD 50 list, all 50 stocks gave up ground at the start of trade, with drugmakers and biotechs leading the losses.Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) tumbled 4%, putting the stock down 9% for the week and looking at a retest of support at its 40-week moving average.Generic-drug maker Lannett (LCI) shed 4%, diving further below its 10-week line and to a 10% decline so far this week.

Another volatile session in China and some major moves among emerging market currencies on Thursday, combined with reaction to the Federal Reserve's on-the-fence position regarding a rate increase in September, rattled global markets and sent the stock market today to an emphatically weak start.

All three leading indexes dived in early trade. The Nasdaq swooned 1.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.3% and the S&P 500 dumped 1.2%. Volume was mixed, down 2% on the Nasdaq, up 23% on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.
An uptick in weekly jobless claims may have added to early pressure, although numbers remained in what the Federal Reserve generally considers constructive territory.

Existing-home sales jumped in July to an annualized pace of 5.59 million, the National Association of Realtors said. That was well above an upwardly revised 5.48 million pace in June, as well as the 5.4 million home sales projected by economist consensus.

Also on the positive side, Philadelphia region manufacturing rose in August, with the Philadelphia Federal Reserve putting its regional manufacturing survey at 8.3 for the month — up from 5.7 in July and comfortably clearing consensus forecasts of 7.5.
In stocks, Merck (MRK) and Walt Disney (DIS) posted the heaviest declines on the Dow, down nearly 4% apiece.

NetApp (NTAP) rose 5% after a strong fiscal Q1 report and stepped out as the early leader on the Nasdaq and the S&P 500. Tech Data (TECD), a maker of peripheral and networking electronics and software, spiked 17% after a big Q2 beat.
Coal, gold and ore miners and oil producers showed early strength. Managed care insurers and security software developers showed some of the worst early losses among industries.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) veered 4% lower after announcing it would by Sprout Pharmaceuticals for about $1 billion. Sprout developed the women's libido drug Addyi, approved by the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday. Valeant expects the deal to close in the third quarter. The loss pulled shares back to a test of support at its 10-week moving average.

Micron Technology (MU) lopped off a 4% loss after Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock to neutral, from outperform, and slashed the stock's price target to 15, from 36. Oversupply in the DRAM — dynamic random access memory —market is the issue, with prices set to fall 20% by early next year. Micron has been in a steepening correction since December.
The IBB 50 list was, again, nearly unanimously lower at the open.
Wisdomtree Investments (WETF) and Ebix (EBIX) dropped 3% each. CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Universal Insurance (UVE) fell nearly that much.

At the top of the list, United Therapeutics (UTHR) rose a shade less than 1%. Data storage startup Tintri, a marketing partner of VMware (VMW), raised $125 million in a funding round, nearly doubling its venture capital investments. Mountain View, Calif.-based Tintri competes with NetApp (NTAP) as well as Nimble Storage (NMBL) and IBM (IBM). Tintri, founded by a former VMware executive, supports data storage in virtualized computing environments. The startup has been a partner…
Stock futures pointed sharply lower Thursday, as an amalgam of uncertainty regarding China, European growth and a Federal Reserve policy shift weakened investors' confidence.
Dow futures toppled 134.7 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures dived 30.2 points. S&P 500 futures dropped 14.5 points.

The stock market today appears set to open with the S&P 500 well below its 200-day moving average and the Nasdaq headed for a test of support at that line. It's obviously shaping up to be a tough day and it could mean that markets are about to blow out of their monthlong trading range and into a correction. The S&P 500 had broken sharply below its 200-day line, then recovered in the same session to retake support on Aug. 12.

It also spent four days in the second week of July tinkering with the 200-day level, only to launch into a four-session advance that retook its 50-day line. Wednesday's session showed institutional investors were clearly in a selling mood. The uptrend under pressure status already counseled investors to be cautious, and increased volatility should amp up that alert.

Economic news showed jobless claims again ticking higher, to 277,000, in the week ended Aug. 15, according to the Labor Department. Analysts had projected a decline to 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average climbed to 271,500, its first increase in five weeks.

Later this morning, the National Association of Realtors delivers July existing-home sales, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve reports regional manufacturing activity for August and the Conference Board serves up its July leading indicators index, all at 10 a.m. ET.
In stocks, all 30 Dow components were down ahead of the open. Walt Disney (DIS) fell hardest, down 2%. Home Depot (HD) and Visa (V) shed 1.2% each.
Gold miners were climbing, with Gold Fields (GFI) up 7%, AngloGold Ashanti (AU) ahead 8% and Randgold Resources (GOLD) rising 3%.
Investors were again punishing some China-based stocks harshly.
Jumei International (JMEI) tumbled 7% despite strong second-quarter results. Momo (MOMO) dropped 4% and Internet TV provider Youku Tudou (YOKU) dropped 3%.
NetApp (NTAP) popped 6% after topping fiscal Q1 earnings estimates and seeing revenue slip 10%, less than expected. Management raised its Q2 guidance to above consensus views.
The stock has been in a nose-down correction since December.

Apparel brand Perry Ellis (PERY) lofted an 8% premarket gain. The Miami-based outfit reported big second-quarter beats for earnings and revenue, and hoisted its full-year 2016 EPS guidance above consensus forecasts. The stock ended Wednesday 17% below a May high and below its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages.
Leaders were generally in the red ahead of the open. On the IBD 50 list, the biggest losses came from Ambarella (AMBA), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and CyberArk Software (CYBR), down about 2% each.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) rose a fraction in heavy trade after announcing it would pay about $1 billion for Sprout Pharmaceutical, the maker of a women's libido booster. The company expects the deal to close in the third quarter. Valeant ended Wednesday in a test of 10-week support, just below an Aug. 6 high.

Oil dropped more than 1% to just above $40 a barrel in the U.S. and with Europe's Brent crude near $46. Oil prices are down in nine of 10 recent weeks to their weakest levels since February 2009. Gold climbed 1% to $1,138, tracking a bit more than 2% higher for the week. Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.
Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.
Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.
Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.

Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.

Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares of the maker of fitness trackers bounced back Monday after hitting a record low Friday.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.

Nimble Storage (NMBL) could be the hottest acquisition target in the storage market.And Cisco Systems (CSCO), NetApp and EMC are the likeliest buyers, says Srini Nandury, an analyst for Summit Partners, in a research report Tuesday."The storage industry is ripe for consolidation and we believe OEMs such as NetApp (NTAP), EMC (EMC) and Cisco are looking to acquire next-generation storage assets," he wrote. "Given that Nimble is one of the best hybrid storage assets in the market, any buyout offer for Nimble will likely trigger a bidding war as we have previously seen with both Data Domain and 3Par."And, given that Nimble is executing solidly in both small and medium-sized business and storage environments, and is expected to roll out both Network-attached storage and Object storage in the near term (12-18 months) and will most likely get acquired, we reiterate our buy rating on the stock and maintain our 40 price target."Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) acquired 3Par for $2.35 billion in 2010, a year after EMC picked up Data Domain for $2.4 billion. Recently, EMC used a separate acquisition to help boost its cloud business.Though Nimble isn't profitable, it's posted year-over-year revenue growth of 89%, 77%, 64% and 53% in its past four quarters.Nimble stock was up more than 2% in morning trading in the stock market today, at a five-month high above 28. Nimble stock is up nearly 25% since April 1 and sports an IBD Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A+. That indicates heavy institutional buying of the stock of late."The company is executing well and has shown solid momentum in its most recent quarter, and we expect the momentum to continue for the rest of the year," Nandury wrote. "Though the company continues to report solid growth, in our view, much of the price appreciation has been driven by the belief that Nimble is THE acquisition candidate. We tend to agree."

Momentary excitement over the minutes of the Fed's April meeting faded in late afternoon trading Wednesday, leaving the major indexes narrowly mixed. The Nasdaq rose a fraction, while the S&P; 500 fell 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped less than 0.2% in the stock market today. Volume was lower across the board, according to preliminary data.The Fed minutes revealed that some members thought interest rates could be raised in June, but they were outnumbered by those who thought they should be raised later.After the close, Williams-Sonoma (WSM) was up. It reported better-than-expected Q1 results. The stock may be building a new base, but is struggling to stay above its 50-day moving average.Salesforce.com (CRM) also rose sharply. It topped expectations, and set FY2016 guidance above the Street's view.NetApp (NTAP) fell after hours. It missed Q4 estimates and guided below Wall Street views. The company announced a dividend increase by 9% to 18 cents a share.Before the market opens Thursday, the Labor Department releases jobless claims for the week ended May 16. Economists expect 270,000 new claims vs. 264,000 in the prior week.At 10 a.m. ET, April existing-home sales are forecast at 5.22 million units, just above 5.19 million for March.

Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. Stocks crept above early losses into thin gains early Thursday, despite a raft of weak economic news.
The Nasdaq shed its losses and grabbed a 0.25 gain. The S&P 500 added 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average fought to hold a fractional gain.
Trade was soft in the stock market today, down 13% on the Nasdaq and 3% lower on the NYSE vs. action at the same time on Wednesday.
The preliminary May purchasing managers index from Markit dipped to 53.8, down from a final reading of 54.2 in April and disappointing consensus projections for an increase to 54.6.

April existing-home sales were also weaker than expected, with the National Association of Realtors reporting sales at an annualized rate of 5.04 million for the month, down from an upwardly revised 5.21 million in March. Forecasts called for an uptick to 5.22 million.

Mid-Atlantic region manufacturing slowed in May, lowering the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey to 6.7 vs. 7.5 in April. Consensus had called for an increase to 8.0.

The one warm spot in the chilly data was the Conference Board's leading economic indicators index, which ticked up 0.7% in April, better than March's 0.2% increase and more than double economist forecasts for a 0.3% gain.

The dollar and oil prices imposed some impact on early trade. The dollar turned mixed, down vs. the euro, up against the yen. Crude oil continued its early bounce, sending the West Texas Intermediate benchmark up nearly 2% to above $60 a barrel.

At the top of the S&P 500, Salesforce.com (CRM) jumped 5%, and Best Buy (BBY) surged 4%. Amazon.com (AMZN) led the Nasdaq 100 with a 2% gain. Retail sector stocks posted some of the morning's most dramatic moves: Kirkland's (KIRK) swept up 13% on strong first-quarter results. Bon-Ton Stores (BONT) collapsed 8% after a wide Q1 earnings miss.

Trina Solar (TSL) rocketed 15% after earnings and revenue easily cleared analyst first-quarter consensus forecasts. The China-based solar power component maker guided expectations for Q2 shipments to better than double that of the first quarter. The stock's jump easily cleared a 13.43 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Bluebird Bio (BLUE) spiked 10% upon announcing that its gene therapy LentiGlobin showed "very encouraging" results in tests vs. sickle cell anemia and beta thalassemia. The Cambridge, Mass.-based company said more data would be presented in June. The gain drove Bluebird shares well into new highs, extended above a rebound from 10-week support and a March breakout.

On the injured list, NetApp (NTAP) crumbled 12% as a spate of analyst downgrades followed a weak fourth-quarter report delivered late Wednesday. Earnings and revenue missed consensus targets, and management gave Q1 guidance to well below analyst expectations. NetApp shares have been in a general downtrend since December.
Leading stocks opened in a positive mode, with 3-in-5 IBD 50 stocks advancing at the starting bell. Gains and losses were moderate.

Criteo (CRTO) rose 2% to the top of the list. As its rivalry with data center software leader VMware (VMW) grows, hot startup Nutanix's product roadmap also spells trouble for NetApp (NTAP), says investment bank Jefferies in a research report. Nutanix, a maker of server and data storage systems that run on network management software, strutted out new alliances at a user conference in Miami this week. San Jose, Calif.-based…

After-hours earnings results, buyout buzz and a lawsuit settlement were the catalysts for stock gains and losses for big-name companies late Wednesday, including Salesforce.com (CRM), Williams-Sonoma (WSM), CVS Health (CVS) and Halliburton (HAL).
 Salesforce.com topped first-quarter estimates as adjusted earnings jumped 45% to 16 cents and sales climbed 23% to $1.51 billion.

The provider of customer relationship management software expects Q2 adjusted EPS of 17 cents to 18 cents vs. forecasts for 17 cents. Salesforce.com's Q2 revenue expectation of $1.59 billion to $1.6 billion beats Wall Street's predictions for $1.58 billion.
Shares popped 6.6% after the bell. If that trend continues into Thursday's regular session, shares could potentially be back in buy range from a flat base with a 71.10 buy point.
 Williams-Sonoma reported Q1 earnings that came in flat at 48 cents per share, topping estimates by 4 cents. Revenue rose almost 6% to $1.03 billion, above consensus expectations for $1.01 billion.
Comparable brand revenue increased 4.6% in the quarter, with Williams-Sonoma's West Elm furniture store chain leading the way with 15.3% comp growth.
Shares pushed up 4% late. The home furnishings retailer is working on a flat base with an 84.85 buy point.

 Design software maker Synopsys (SNPS) said that its fiscal Q2 EPS rose 5% to 68 cents while revenue increased 7.6% to $557.2 mil. Both topped expectations. For Q3, Synopsys sees earnings of 58-60 cents a share, short of Wall Street views for 66 cents.
Shares sank 1.5% after hours. Shares have been trading in buy range from a flat base with a 47.47 buy point for the past nine straight sessions.
 L Brands (LB) reported first-quarter earnings that grew 13% to an adjusted 61 cents, topping Wall Street calculations by a penny. Revenue climbed 5% to $2.51 billion, below expectations.
L Brands' Q2 EPS guidance of 60-65 cents was also short of estimates for 69 cents.
Shares dipped 0.9% in extended trading. The stock has been building a flat base with a 95.88 buy point.
 NetApp (NTAP) missed fiscal Q4 expectations as earnings fell 23% and revenue dropped 7%. The data storage firm also issued weak Q1 guidance.
Shares tumbled 7.9% after the bell. NetApp is trading below its 50-day and 200-day lines and is about 19% off of a 43.75 high set last September.
 CVS Health is in advanced talks to buy Cincinnati-based pharmacy distributor Omnicare (OCR), according to Bloomberg News sources.

With a market cap of $9.2 billion, Omnicare has been rallying over the past month amid talk of a takeover. Shares are approaching the 20% profit-taking zone from a flat base buy point of 79.80, which it initially cleared on April 21.
CVS shares got a 0.2% bump late after closing down 1%.
 And oil-field services firm Halliburton reached a settlement with BP (BP), resolving issues related to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon Gulf oil spill. Terms were not disclosed.
Shares edged down 0.4% after hours, while BP was little changed.

Q1 earnings could be a tale of winners and losers, with companies likeHewlett-Packard (HPQ) and EMC on the short end, and analytics firms like Tableau and Splunk doing well. Customer demand for cloud, security and analytics products held up well in Q1, but PCs and storage were the two weakest tech segments last quarter, Brent Bracelin, an analyst for Pacific…

Global sales of enterprise disk storage systems reached $10.57 billion in the fourth quarter at the factory level, up 7.2% from the year-earlier period, says research firm IDC.EMC (EMC), the longtime leader, retained its No. 1 spot with a 22% market share, down from 21% in Q4 2013. EMC's Q4 revenue in disk storage systems totaled $2.35 billion.Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) was No. 2 with a 13.8% share. HP maintained its Q4 lead in server sales, however.Dell was No. 3 in disk storage system sales last quarter, while IBM (IBM) and NetApp (NTAP) tied for the fourth position."The storage market had a strong finish to 2014," IDC analyst Eric Sheppard said in a press release."Fourth-quarter spending on enterprise storage systems was up strongly in most major geographic markets, driven by traditional year-end seasonality, demand for midrange systems that incorporate flash capacity, and continued growth of systems designed for hyperscale datacenters," he said.Storage systems sales by original design manufacturers selling directly to hyperscale datacenter customers accounted for 12.8% of global spending during the quarter.Disk storage system spending for the year rose 3.6% to $36.2 billion.IDC defines a disk storage system as a packaged set of storage elements, including disk drives, controllers and cables.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and FireEye topped the list of security stocks in a survey of resellers and distributors across the U.S. and Europe.Other security companies that did well in a survey of more than three dozen distributors included Barracuda Networks (CUDA) and CyberArk Software (CYBR), Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski said in a research report Monday."We noted the strongest results from Palo Alto Networks and FireEye (FEYE), with 54% and 43% of resellers 'above plan,'" Nowinski said. "This was the highest percentage of above plan responses for Palo Alto Networks since the fourth quarter of 2013. As such, Palo Alto Networks and FireEye remain as our top two favorite ideas in the security space."Some 60% of resellers expect Palo Alto Networks to post sales above normal seasonality in the June quarter, Nowinski said.Palo Alto Networks stock was down more than 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 146. Palo Alto Networks continues to act well, supported by its 10-week moving average. But the stock is extended 13% past its latest buy point of 129.52.FireEye was highlighted in a segment on Sunday's episode of "60 Minutes," as Steve Kroft interviewed FireEye Chief Operating Officer Kevin Mandia about the company's efforts to help Sony clean up the fallout of a cyberattack it suffered in November.FireEye stock was down 2.5% in afternoon trading Monday, near 42.IBD's Computer Software-Security group ranks No. 5 among the 197 that IBD tracks.Other security companies that stood out among resellers included Fortinet (FTNT), Imperva (IMPV) and Proofpoint (PFPT), the Piper Jaffray report said.Symantec (SYMC), which was also on the list, was the topic of a separate research report Monday, in which Cowen & Co. analyst Gregg Moskowitz said a news report about Symantec possibly spinning off its Veritas information management business could be a positive for the security company.The Wall Street Journal reported Friday that Symantec is exploring the possibility of selling its Veritas business, and could get more than $8 billion for it, citing "people familiar with the matter."Symantec stock was down 5% Monday afternoon, near 24.Symantec announced in October that it plans to split the company in two, spinning off Veritas by year-end.Moskowitz said Oracle (ORCL), NetApp (NTAP) and EMC (EMC) are potential Veritas buyers."Given Veritas' low-growth profile and tough competition, we believe this would be a good exit for Symantec ...," Moskowitz said.RELATED:CyberArk Stock Gets Jolt From Rebound Off Key Area.

Red Hat is benefiting from an expanding business model. The enterprise software company on Wednesday followed a strong Q3 report in December with fourth-quarter earnings that beat analyst estimates, as the company grows beyond its core Linux operating system software. Red Hat's  (RHT) earnings outlook for the current quarter was ahead of views. But its sales target was below…

Storage systems provider NetApp (NTAP) was upgraded by UBS to buy from neutral, based on improving market conditions. UBS also raised its price target on NetApp to 50 from 42. NetApp stock was up 1.7% in afternoon trading in the stock market Monday, near 43. "Although we don't see overall storage demand rebounding yet, NetApp's market opportunity has expanded and…
Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) remains a work in progress.
The global computer products giant isn't expected to do any better than meet analyst expectations when it reports its fiscal fourth-quarter results after the market close Tuesday.

HP is working through a troublesome restructuring process with a plan to build up its enterprise, software, storage and other businesses to offset declining and flat growth in its core PC and printing units. HP is the world's No. 2 PC seller, having lost its crown to China-based Lenovo.
For the quarter ended Oct. 31, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect HP to report earnings per share minus items of $1, down from $1.16 in the year-earlier quarter.
Revenue is expected to fall 6.8% to $27.9 billion.

"We expect HP to report fiscal Q4 in line with expectations as PC/server stabilization is offset by federal/EM (emerging market) head winds," Katy Huberty, an analyst for Morgan Stanley, wrote in a research note Friday.
The company faces the same market factors affecting its peers, Amit Daryanani, an analyst for RBC Capital Markets, said in a research note Thursday.

"We think HP, like its peers (IBM (IBM), Cisco Systems (CSCO), EMC (EMC), NetApp (NTAP) etc.) witnessed head winds within Asia-Pacific (China) and U.S. federal," he wrote. "Positively, HP may have seen more stable trends within printing as they saw muted benefits from back-to-school coupled with lean inventory in the channel.
"PCs should remain a focal point during the quarter, not so much for the revenue/EPS contribution but rather implications to free cash flow."
For the current quarter, analysts expect HP to report EPS ex items, of 85 cents, up from 82 cents in the year-ago period.
Revenue is expected to fall 5.4% to $26.8 billion.

In fiscal 2002 (ended in April that year), sales totaled $798 million. Despite two recessions in…

Analyst actions on Thursday included price-target hikes for Cisco Systems (CSCO), NetApp (NTAP), Applied Materials (AMAT) and CBS (CBS), while Wells Fargo (WFC) got a downgrade.UBS raised its price target for the networking equipment company to 37 from 35, and Deutsche Bank hiked its target to 40, after Cisco topped second-quarter earnings estimates and increased its dividend late Wednesday. Both firms have buy ratings on Cisco.UBS analyst Steven Milunovich sees M&As in Cisco's future, saying even big deals will be considered. While a tax cut on profits held overseas, as planned by the Trump administration, could help facilitate a deal, Milunovich doesn't see a repatriation as being essential for a deal to happen.Shares of Cisco closed up 2.4% at 33.60 on the stock market today. The stock is now extended from a 31.99 buy point cleared this week.RELATED:Cisco Earnings, Revenue Edge Views; Dividend Hike Light? IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Cisco broke above a five-month trading range on Monday and has kept climbing. Early Thursday, shares were just barely less than 5% above the buy point, meaning it's not quite too extended. Check out IBD Leaderboard to find other leading stocks near a buy point.Analysts hiked their price targets on the maker of storage and data-management products after it topped fiscal Q3 estimates and grew revenue for the first time in 13 quarters.UBS lifted its target on NetApp to 37 from 32, but kept a sell rating. Analyst Steven Milunovich noted lower gross margins, which suggests discounting helped revenue grow.Piper Jaffray lifted its target to 49 from 46, with an overweight rating. Analyst Andrew Nowinski thinks NetApp has "turned the corner" and that revenue can rise by mid-single-digit percentages.Shares advanced 4.2% to finish at 40.56 after rising as high as 42.18 in the morning.RELATED:NetApp Turnaround Comes Into Focus With Earnings BeatRBC Capital Markets raised its price target from the chip-equipment maker to 35 from 30, keeping a sector perform rating after Applied Materials beat Q1 estimates and offered better-than-expected guidance. Analyst Amit Daryanani expects the company to increase its share of wafer fab equipment spending and noted that display revenue continues to surprise to the upside.Shares of Applied Materials rose modestly initially, but reversed to close down 0.9% at 35.18.RELATED:Applied Materials Beats Q1 Targets, Guides Higher, Stock Rises RBC Capital Markets raised its price target for the diversified media company to 78 from 70, keeping an outperform rating, after CBS reported Q4 earnings that topped estimates. Revenue was weaker than expected, partly due to NFL ratings.Shares of CBS gained 0.3% to 65.42.Credit Suisse downgraded the banking giant to neutral from outperform, with a 56 price target, citing valuation. The stock touched an all-time high this week and has surged about 29% since the election on expectations of higher interest rates, deregulation and tax cuts.Shares of Wells Fargo dipped 0.7% to 58.12.RELATED:Fed Chief Yellen's Hawkish Tone Lifts Bond Yields, Bank StocksCummins, Wells Fargo Boast Healthy Yields, Bullish Charts
Stocks opened narrowly mixed on Friday, as the currency effects stirred by China early in the week settled and oil prices imposed some mild upward pressure on the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Nasdaq was effectively flat in early action.
Trading got off to a soft start in the stock market today, with volume down 11% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE.

Oil prices were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate up more than 1%, and Brent crude down a fraction. WTI was tracking toward a steep loss for the week, while Brent was up about 1%. Energy stocks will be keeping an eye out for Baker Hughes' weekly rig count, which is due out at 1 p.m. ET.

The Labor Department reported earlier producer prices rose 0.2% in July, up 0.3% minus energy and food. That was slightly above expectations and below June's 0.4% gain — showing inflation continuing to run below the 2% pace the Fed says would trigger a rate increase.

Industrial production popped 0.6% in July, the Federal Reserve reported, while downgrading June's increase to 0.1% from 0.2%. Consensus views looked for a 0.4% jump in July. Capacity utilization eased slightly to 78% vs. 78.4% in June and forecasts for 78.1%.
August consumer sentiment cooled, putting the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index at 92.2 for the month, down from 93.1. and disappointing expectations for an increase to 93.5.
In stocks, Nordstrom (JWN) led the S&P 500 index, followed by a long list of energy and oil-related companies. DuPont (DD) led the Dow with a 1.4% gain.

Chip equipment makers were under some early pressure after Applied Materials (AMAT) reported fiscal Q3 earnings in line with consensus expectations, but revenue and Q4 guidance below forecasts. Applied dropped 3%, deepening its five-month correction. Smaller peer ASML Holding (ASML) also fell 3%, setting a new low in its two-month consolidation.

A weak Q2 earnings report didn't keep China-based WuXi Pharmatech (WX) from surging 5% at the open. A management group landed a $3.3 billion deal to buy the provider of clinical trials for drugmakers, in a deal that would take the company off the U.S. stock market. The company gave no timeline for the $46-per share deal to be completed. The gain punched the stock back above its 50-day moving average, leaving it just below its mid-May high.

Three out of five leaders opened lower on the IBD 50 list. CyberArk Software (CYBR) led the upside after Wells Fargo upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Shares remain below their 10-week moving average in a two-month consolidation and below a prior buy point of 69.10.

Losses were narrow, with Tesoro's (TSO) 1% slip being the deepest cut. Stocks ended with solid gains Friday after battling back from weakness spurred by a disappointing jobs report. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 ended up 1.7% and 1.4%, respectively. Both were down 1.6% at Friday's low. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.2%. According to preliminary data, volume ended higher across the board in the stock market today.Among leading stocks, Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) reversed higher to a 6% gain. The stock had already risen 3% Thursday, following the pricing of a share offering. Dave & Buster's was recently featured in Stock Spotlight.Verisk Analytics (VRSK) stretched its win streak to four straight sessions. It rebounded from a 2% loss and rose 2%. The stock nearly reached a 79.98 buy point in a flat base. Verisk, which provides data to insurance underwriters and banks, will be added to the S&P 500 after Wednesday's close.Tyler Technologies (TYL) added 2% for its second straight new high. It's now 15% past a 145.84 buy point from a flat base cleared Sept. 14. On Thursday, the company announced that it would buy privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock.Domino's Pizza (DPZ) climbed 0.5% after bucking morning weakness. It failed to retake its 200-day moving average. Domino's will report Q3 earnings Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the pizza chain's profit rising 17% to 74 cents a share..
Riverbed Technology (RVBD) is leaving Wall Street.

The computing networking equipment maker on Monday said it agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Thomas Bravo and Teachers' Private Capital, the private investor department of Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, for $3.6 billion. That comes to $21 a share, 12% above the company's closing price on Friday. Riverbed stock hasn't traded above 21 since March.
The company expects the acquisition to close in the first half of 2015.
Riverbed stock was up 9%, near 20.45, in morning trading in the stock market today.
Speculation of a Riverbed sale had been rampant for months, spurred by Elliott Management, a private equity firm and one of its shareholders, which had made a $3.36 billion offer for the company.

"While it has been a tough few years for Riverbed (and its investors), given the company's inconsistent performance on the heels of both company-specific (execution issues) challenges and integration issues (e.g., OpNet acquisition), we believe it is nice to see the final chapter in the Elliott activism story closed, although we believe Riverbed could have ultimately seen a higher price in this bidding process if the company had sought out strategic alternatives before execution issues surfaced," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research report. "In our opinion, this morning's acquisition speaks to our belief that Riverbed remains a core strategic asset within the broader technology food chain and that M&A activity in the software space will remain alive and well heading into 2015 as larger technology players and private equity look to capitalize on a healthy IT spending environment."

On Oct. 9, Riverbed preannounced a third-quarter earnings miss and said it would launch a restructuring plan. On Oct. 24, Riverbed sold its SteelStore cloud storage product line to NetApp (NTAP) for $80 million.
Even with the recent divestiture and restructuring plan, a sale seemed inevitable, says Jason Ader, an analyst for William Blair & Co. in a research report Monday.

"We viewed this as a likely outcome, with previous diversification efforts showing mixed progress and wide area network optimization secularly challenged, making it increasingly difficult to attach a 'growth' label to Riverbed's business," he wrote. "Additionally, with a set of high-quality assets at differing levels of maturity as well as healthy profitability and cash flow, private ownership may allow Riverbed to thrive in a way not possible in the public market."Riverbed Technology (RVBD) is leaving Wall Street.The computing networking equipment maker on Monday said it agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Thomas Bravo and Teachers' Private Capital, the private investor department of Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, for $3.6 billion. That comes to $21 a share, 12% above the company's closing price on Friday. Riverbed stock hasn't traded above 21 since March.The company expects the acquisition to close in the first half of 2015.Riverbed stock was up 9%, near 20.45, in morning trading in the stock market today.Speculation of a Riverbed sale had been rampant for months, spurred by Elliott Management, a private equity firm and one of its shareholders, which had made a $3.36 billion offer for the company."While it has been a tough few years for Riverbed (and its investors), given the company's inconsistent performance on the heels of both company-specific (execution issues) challenges and integration issues (e.g., OpNet acquisition), we believe it is nice to see the final chapter in the Elliott activism story closed, although we believe Riverbed could have ultimately seen a higher price in this bidding process if the company had sought out strategic alternatives before execution issues surfaced," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research report. "In our opinion, this morning's acquisition speaks to our belief that Riverbed remains a core strategic asset within the broader technology food chain and that M&A activity in the software space will remain alive and well heading into 2015 as larger technology players and private equity look to capitalize on a healthy IT spending environment."On Oct. 9, Riverbed preannounced a third-quarter earnings miss and said it would launch a restructuring plan. On Oct. 24, Riverbed sold its SteelStore cloud storage product line to NetApp (NTAP) for $80 million.Even with the recent divestiture and restructuring plan, a sale seemed inevitable, says Jason Ader, an analyst for William Blair & Co. in a research report Monday."We viewed this as a likely outcome, with previous diversification efforts showing mixed progress and wide area network optimization secularly challenged, making it increasingly difficult to attach a 'growth' label to Riverbed's business," he wrote. "Additionally, with a set of high-quality assets at differing levels of maturity as well as healthy profitability and cash flow, private ownership may allow Riverbed to thrive in a way not possible in the public market."

The bulls failed to mount a counter-attack to Tuesday's sell-off, and stocks finished mildly lower Wednesday in light trading. The Nasdaq fell less than 0.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 0.3% in the stock market today. Volume on both exchanges was lighter than Monday, according to preliminary data.
Volkswagen (VLKAY) jumped nearly 7% as its board accepted the resignation of CEO Martin Winterkorn in the wake of a scandal over cheating on emissions tests. The stock is still down 25% this week.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 36 were higher and 14 were lower. The top performer was AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), up more than 3% to a new high. The company, which supplies health care facilities with doctors and nurses, announced the acquisition of First String Healthcare.
Egg Producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM), another IBD 50 name, rose nearly 3%. It's building the right side of a base.
Another provider of nurses and doctors, Cross Country Healthcare (CCRN), rose nearly 4% in above-average volume to a new high.

Synchronoss Technologies (SNCR) fell 11% in monster volume. An analyst reportedly said the company might lose Verizon (VZ) as a cloud customer. The major indexes hit record or multiyear highs intraday Thursday but ended off those levels.

Helped by Wal-Mart (WMT), which reported better-than-expected earnings, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%. The Nasdaq backed off from a fresh 14-year high to end with a 0.1% gain. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 was fractionally higher after notching another record high early in the session. Volume rose across the board in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.

Sierra Wireless (SWIR) stretched its win streak to six straight sessions. It added 4% in heavy trading. Intraday, the stock climbed as much as 28% past a 30.65 buy point from a cup base cleared Nov. 6. That surge on Nov. 6 was sparked by its solid Q3 earnings.

Alibaba (BABA) reversed from a new high and lost 3%. Intraday, the stock triggered IBD's eight-week hold rule for handling fast movers. It cleared a 99.80 buy point from an IPO base Nov. 6. The Chinese e-commerce giant proposed a bond offering less than two months after going public.
NetApp (NTAP) slumped 3% in reaction to late Wednesday's mixed fiscal Q2 results. Earnings eked by views, but sales narrowly mixed. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base with a 43.77 buy point.

Data on retail sales, consumer sentiment and import and export prices will be out Friday. Stocks climbed out of the starting gate Thursday, as investors looked past soft unemployment and jobs data.
The Nasdaq pumped up 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% each.
Trade dipped 4% on the NYSE but rose 8% on the Nasdaq vs. action at the same time Wednesday.
The stock market today felt some early drag from data showing a larger-than-expected rise in weekly unemployment claims.

The Labor Department also reported 4.74 million job openings in its September Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey. That was down from an upwardly revised 4.85 million for August, disappointing expectations for a mild decline to 4.8 million. The quits number increased, however, showing more workers comfortable enough to leave their jobs. And the number of hires hit 5 million for the month, its highest since December 2007.

In stocks, among the morning's biggest gainers and losers, DreamWorks Animation (DWA) sketched out a 16% advance at the open. News reports said the company was discussing a possible takeover by toy maker Hasbro (HAS) .
J.C. Penney (JCP) dropped 8%, as revenue slipped vs. expectations for an increase, and despite a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss.

Wal-Mart (WMT) broke character and snapped up 4% to a new high after its third-quarter results surprised analysts. A penny per share increase topped expectations for a 2-cent decline. Revenue rose a much better-than-expected 3%. Overall same-store sales rose 0.5%, above forecasts, boosted by a surprise 5.5% leap in comparable sales at Wal-Mart's small format Neighborhood Store chain. The move sent shares above their November 2011 high.

Data storage powerhouse NetApp (NTAP) slumped 4%, despite narrowly topping third-quarter earnings expectations. Revenue was flat however, and just short of analyst estimates. Q4 earnings guidance came in just below consensus views. The stock is in the eighth week of a cup-with-handle base.

Leading stocks set off on a positive note, with nearly four in every five IBD 50 stocks gaining ground at the open. Gains were on the thin side, with AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) up almost 2% and leading the early advance. The workers compensation and specialty insurer is 12% above a 46.12 buy point after a couple of volatile weeks.

Stocks squeezed out small gains in a listless session Tuesday.
The Nasdaq edged up 0.2% and the S&P 500 rose 0.1%. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average eked out a fractional gain.
Volume dropped off on both major exchanges in the stock market today due to Veterans Day. The bond market was closed.

After the close, shares of Fossil Group (FOSL) shot up 15% on better-than-expected Q3 results. The maker of watches and accessories posted earnings of $1.96 a share on sales on $894.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected a profit of $1.82 a share on revenue of $879.05 million.

Better-than-expected quarterly results also boosted YY (YY). The Chinese social media firm reported earnings of 87 cents a share, up 85% from 47 cents in the year-ago period. Views were for 76 cents a share. Sales more than doubled to $163 million, beating views for $152.54 million. It rose 2% in extended trading.
Fellow leading stocks moved in Tuesday's regular session.

D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 2% in heavy trading after reporting mixed quarterly results. Before the open, the homebuilder reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 45 cents a share, up 12% but 3 cents below views. Q3 profit had declined 24%. But sales grew 33% to more than $2.4 billion, which topped expectations. The stock cleared a 23.41 buy point from a handle in a double-bottom base Monday.

Lennar (LEN) climbed 2% and stretched its win streak to five sessions. It's now 10% past a 42.07 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. In September, the homebuilder beat views with a 44% increase in Q3 earnings and a 26% rise in sales.
Alibaba (BABA) fell 4%, ending a red hot, six-session win streak. Shares were weak Tuesday despite news that the Chinese e-commerce giant did a record $9.3 billion in transactions on Singles Day.

Alibaba was also on the receiving end of some positive actions by analysts. Oppenheimer started coverage with an outperform rating and a 133 price target. Bank of America/Merrill Lynch raised its price target to 132 from 122.

Analysts are divided on NetApp's growth prospects after the data-management company's analyst day, but at least four investment banks raised their price targets on the stock.Not all investors are convinced. NetApp (NTAP) stock was down more than 1% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 35.50.Piper Jaffray raised its price target on the company to 42 a share from 40, and Brean Capital to 42 from 39. Pacific Crest Securities upped its target to 41 from 40, while Macquarie Group increased its target to 38 from 36.At Tuesday's analyst day event, NetApp executives reiterated their forecast for the current quarter. It calls for earnings per share minus items of 53 cents to 58 cents, vs. 53 cents in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect 57 cents.The company expects revenue of $1.42 billion and $1.52 billion, down 5.9% to flat, where analysts expect $1.47 billion.Jason Ader, an analyst for William Blair, says in a research note that the company retained some optimism in spite of industry challenges."Management noted that the storage market remains challenged because of constrained IT budgets, elongated product life cycles, new cloud delivery models and a plethora of new platform choices that are resulting in slower customer purchasing decisions," he wrote. "Management based its growth forecast on the expectation that their transition off of legacy point products, and that customers will begin to architect the cloud into their IT environments."But Ader retained his underperform rating on the stock, unconvinced about its near-term growth prospects."We believe that management's growth forecast represents mostly an aspirational goal at this point, and we remain firm in our view that intensifying structural headwinds are just as responsible for weak storage spending as are cyclical issues," he wrote.In a research report, Steven Milunovich, an analyst for UBS Securities, said that, "Overall, we came out of the analyst meeting slightly more optimistic. NetApp's three-year financial outlook included a muted revenue recovery but a higher gross margin leading to EPS gains of around 10-12% or twice (the) expected mid-single-digit branded revenue growth."Last month, Ader offered a much more optimistic assessment of NetApp rival Nimble Storage.

NetApp (NTAP) enjoys sitting in the nexus of data storage and virtualization. Its results offer solid proof. The explosion of mobile computing and telecom devices and continued growth of Internet use around the world has benefited NetApp for years since its founding in 1992. In fiscal 2002 (ended in April that year), sales totaled $798 million. Despite two recessions in…
The rise of cloud computing is making data centers more important to big companies, and Digital Realty Trust (DLR) likes to think it's the go-to company for that.
Digital Realty is a real estate investment trust that specializes in owning and operating data centers. It operated 131 properties with 24.5 million square feet as of March 31.
It has 1.3 million square feet under development and 1.4 million square feet held for future development.
Many data centers resemble two-story or taller office buildings, but are filled with densely packed servers and cables rather than workers.

Among its clients are ARM Holdings (ARMH), the British chipmaker whose products are found in 95% of the world's smartphones. Digital Realty already had a data center near ARM's headquarters in Cambridge, but the U.K. company needed a big U.S. presence. Digital Realty arranged for it to take over part of an Austin, Texas, data center.
In 2011, NetApp (NTAP) held competitive bidding that was won by Digital Realty, which built for the company a customized data center in Hillsboro, Ore.
The center saves money by using Oregon's cool climate to keep its servers from overheating.
Funds from operation, the REIT equivalent of earnings, have been growing steadily for years, from $1.38 per share in 2005 to $4.79 in 2013. Analysts expect 1% growth in 2014 and 7% growth in 2015.
Quarterly revenue growth has been on the decline. From double-digit growth over the past few years, the company has had two quarters of single-digit revenue growth of 9%.
Earlier this year, Digital Realty raised its quarterly dividend to 83 cents a share from 78 cents. That's up from 15.6315 cents in 2004.

The current dividend works out to a 5.8% annualized rate. Nimble Storage (NMBL) could be on the right track to capturing a much larger portion of the storage software market.
That, at least, is the conclusion of Jason Ader, an analyst for William Blair & Co.

In a note released Monday, Ader raised his rating on the company from market perform to outperform "based on the company's more attractive valuation level, the anticipated addition of Fibre Channel support in 2014, and the general availability of its new scale-out software," he wrote. The latter two developments "should expand the company's addressable market beyond the midrange and enable it to continue taking share from vulnerable incumbents," Ader said.
Nimble's shares jumped by more than 14% on the stock market today.
The company expects to report its first-quarter numbers after the market close on May 29. It launched an IPO on Dec. 13.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Nimble to report a loss per-share, minus items, of 16 cents. Revenue is expected to reach $43.7 million.
Company results should exceed those estimates, Ader says.

"We believe the company will exceed Street estimates for revenue of $44 million (up 98% from the prior year quarter) and raise guidance for the July quarter above the Street target," he wrote. "Despite a tentative storage spending backdrop, our reseller contacts indicate that Nimble continues to fire on all cylinders and is displacing both Dell (Compellent and EqualLogic) and lower-end NetApp (NTAP) deployments in the field thanks to Nimble's compelling price and performance advantages."

For the current quarter, Nimble is expected to report a loss per-share, ex items, of 16 cents. Founded in 1992, NetApp (NTAP) is the second-largest provider of external data storage systems and software, behind EMC. Besides its data storage hardware, NetApp's core software offering is Data OnTap, an operating system that helps users manage companywide data operations, including cloud-computing environments. Software now plays a larger role in data management, a trend called software defined storage. NetApp says…

Data storage vendor NetApp (NTAP), challenged by shifting market conditions and startup competitors, is scheduled to report earnings after the market close Wednesday.NetApp designs, develops and markets networked storage systems and data management software. Its primary competitor is EMC (EMC), but NetApp has also been pressured by competition from developers of flash-based storage systems, as well as cloud-based providers of storage-as-a-service.NetApp is reporting earnings for its fiscal third quarter ended Jan. 24.The consensus estimate among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for revenue of $1.63 billion, even with the year-earlier quarter. NetApp has reported revenue growth in the low single digits for five consecutive quarters, after a long string of double-digit growth.The consensus on earnings per share minus items is 71 cents, up 6%, a slowdown from the previous two quarters of double-digit EPS growth.NetApp stock was up nearly 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 43.65. NetApp stock touched a 22-month high of 45.70 on Jan. 22, but it sports a so-so IBD Relative Strength Rating of 70.Besides its data storage hardware, NetApp's core software offering is Data OnTap, an operating system that helps users manage companywide data operations, including cloud-computing environments.The emergence of cloud computing presents both challenges and opportunities for NetApp. It created a boom in new storage startups that might challenge the company for market share. These include Nimble Storage (NMBL), Pure Storage, Nutanix and Tintri. But the emergence of cloud computing has also advanced the demand for more storage systems due to a rapid expansion in data creation in an increasingly digital world.Brian Marshall, an analyst at International Strategy & Investment, in a research report last month maintained a buy rating on NetApp, with a price target of 48.Of the competition, he wrote, "we believe NetApp has been quietly holding its own. We are also encouraged to see NetApp take steps to better position itself for public cloud environments."Eric Martinuzzi, an analyst at Lake Street Capital Markets, has a buy rating on NetApp, with a price target of 49."Our research indicates key partners are doing better than expected and there has been good follow-through into the new year," he wrote in a research note.But Alex Kurtz, an analyst with Sterne Agee, rates NetApp stock neutral."Discussions with regional and national resellers suggest a changing landscape as new entrants such as Pure, Nutanix, Nimble and Tintri, to name a few, begin to consume mind-share and technical resources with the resellers," he wrote.

Shares of network storage provider NetApp (NTAP) were up after posting mixed quarterly results that included plans to issue a dividend, a new stock buyback program and a 7% reduction in head count. For its fiscal fourth quarter ended April 26, NetApp reported sales of $1.72 billion, up 1% from the year-ago quarter but below consensus estimates of $1.75 billion.…

Long a drag on the company, Oracle's hardware business could finally see steady growth. The business-software giant has used its engineered systems to revive its once-fading hardware business. The strategy resulted in Oracle (ORCL) last quarter reporting the first-ever year-over-year revenue growth for its hardware unit.
